IndieWire‚Äôs ‚Äò70s Week is presented by Bleecker Street‚Äôs ‚ÄúRELAY.‚Äù Riz Ahmed plays a world class ‚Äúfixer‚Äù who specializes in brokering lucrative payoffs between corrupt corporations and the individuals who threaten their ruin. IndieWire calls ‚ÄúRELAY‚Äù ‚Äúsharp, fun, and smartly entertaining from its first scene to its final twist, ‚ÄòRELAY‚Äô is a modern paranoid thriller that harkens back to the genre‚Äôs ‚Äô70s heyday.‚Äù From director David Mackenzie (‚ÄúHell or High Water‚Äù) and also starring Lily James, in theaters August 22. A film like ‚ÄúThe Sugarland Express‚Äù is proof that some legends are just built different. Directing his first theatrically released film at 28 years old, Steven Spielberg practically emerged from the womb with all of the characteristics that would make him the biggest Hollywood director of the next half century: the effortless command of spectacle that always knows when to take a backseat to storytelling, the buttery smooth camera movements that seamlessly shift focus without ever letting viewers know it‚Äôs happening, and his unapologetic sincerity and deep belief in the dreams of brighter days that Hollywood has always sold us. Many a modern viewer has watched ‚ÄúThe Sugarland Express‚Äù expecting a trail of breadcrumbs that point to the development of a more mature Spielberg who directed his best films, but its pleasures are more immediate than that ‚Äî ‚ÄúThe Sugarland Express‚Äù is one of his best films, full stop. In Goldie Hawn‚Äôs Lou Jean, a young mom who will stop at nothing to get her baby out of the foster system, Spielberg found one of his most endearing protagonists. Her endless love, refusal to accept defeat, and good humor about the ridiculousness of riding in a cop convoy while holding an officer at gunpoint makes the character impossible to root against, and Spielberg is often happy to sit back and let Hawn‚Äôs charisma do all the hard work for him. ‚ÄúThe Sugarland Express‚Äù is Spielberg at his funniest and most sincere, complete with stellar car chase sequences that foreshadow his blockbuster dominance, and beautiful shots of characters watching ‚ÄúLooney Tunes‚Äù that may well have laid the foundation for Sammy Fabelman‚Äôs eventual trips to the movies. Its legacy has been overshadowed by the colossal movies its director has made in the subsequent decades, but the film would be just as deserving of a spot on this list if Spielberg had never stepped behind the camera again. ‚ÄîCZ Agn√®s Varda‚Äôs ‚ÄúOne Sings, the Other Doesn‚Äôt‚Äù is a musical about women‚Äôs rights, at once both polemical in its borderline-Brechtian lyrics championing birth control and body autonomy, and also eternally playful and inquisitive in the naturalistic study of its central duo‚Äôs friendship over many years. Classmates Pauline and Suzanne drift together and apart through the vagaries of life, each following a wildly different path but always retaining a connection to the other. Among other things, it is one of the most gently observed movies ever made about female friendship. One of Varda‚Äôs boldest experiments, the film blends various genres and styles. Inspired by a real abortion case, the film incorporates neorealist traits to the extent it casts one of the actual lawyers to recreate the court proceedings, but Varda also sidesteps into gorgeous tableaux vivants and adopts immersive editing patterns to convey the characters‚Äô sense of time passing. And the occasional bursts of song add a dash of whimsy to topics the director takes seriously, using humor and warmth to bring into the open subjects that were still largely taboo in French society. ‚ÄîJC In a way, Edward Anhalt and John Milius‚Äôs script for ‚ÄúJeremiah Johnson‚Äù crystallizes what Westerns have been chasing ever since: It‚Äôs spare, unfussy, and full of poetic character. But for all the ways in which ‚ÄúJeremiah Johnson‚Äù has proven enduring and influential, this under-appreciated classic is a truly singular film at heart ‚Äî a portrait of a true ‚Äò70s loner who just happens to be living in the Rocky Mountains in the 1840s. Drawing inspiration from period vernacular and the poetry of Carl Sandburg, Anhalt and Milius‚Äôs script is laser-focused on the search for what really matters in life, and the search that happens within oneself. Director Sydney Pollack, proving his extraordinary range and gifts, opened himself up as well to find this movie in the edit, a seven-and-a-half month assembly process following a shoot all over the snowy wilds of Redford‚Äôs adopted state of Utah. Far more than ‚ÄúButch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid,‚Äù ‚ÄúJeremiah Johnson‚Äù is the real birth of Sundance ‚Äî many of the landscapes here seem just a stone‚Äôs throw from Main Street in Park City. The result is both purposeful in the writing and loose enough to let in a real feeling of life, the kind of experiential rhythm that you can‚Äôt find in a studio. This is as quiet and most introspective as Westerns get. It also has one of the ultimate ‚Äò70s cinematic moments, an instant that sums up the spirit of the decade onscreen better than maybe any other bit of dialogue. While those opposed to the Vietnam War burned their draft cards, Jeremiah Johnson deserts the army altogether, who were then fighting the Mexican War. Sometime after his abandonment of the fight he encounters a patrol of soldiers and asks if the war is still going. So much time has passed that the patrol‚Äôs officer isn‚Äôt sure which war he means. ‚ÄúThe war against the president of Mexico,‚Äù Jeremiah clarifies. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs over!‚Äù comes the response. So then Jeremiah asks, his tone of voice perfectly calibrated to convey a mix of mild curiosity and ultimate indifference: ‚ÄúWho won?‚Äù ‚ÄîCB One of the great Upper East Side movies, Paul Mazursky‚Äôs feminist romantic dramedy ‚ÄúAn Unmarried Woman‚Äù is also one of the most emotionally intelligent American movies of the 1970s: The story of Erica Benton (Jill Clayburgh), who must come to terms with her husband (Michael Murphy) leaving her for another, what-else-but much younger woman, and set out on the healing and hopeful path to reclaiming herself later in life. (While Clayburgh was in her mid-30s when Mazursky shot the movie, something about her feels older, wiser.) But ‚ÄúAn Unmarried Woman‚Äù is also a sharp feminist text and richly lived-in-feeling portrait of New York City life. Clayburgh‚Äôs superb performance, which was Best Actress-nominated at the 1979 Academy Awards after winning that prize at the 1978 Cannes Film Festival, has a deft and deceptive lightness that gives Erica a sort of floating-through-life, almost gossamer quality that makes her at times tricky to read (and so therefore more fascinating to watch). It‚Äôs also extremely cathartic for the audience. Though Erica, an art dealer, eventually gets acquainted with Alan Bates as an abstract painter, ‚ÄúAn Unmarried Woman‚Äù isn‚Äôt a romantic comedy in search of a match for its leading character. It‚Äôs a more naturalistic, minor-key character study that feels closer in spirit to an indie, landing on a great punchline of an ending as Erica trudges with a giant oversized painting in her arms down the streets of SoHo, a painting given to her by Bates‚Äô artist. That Erica refuses to settle for an alternate relationship is what makes the empowering ‚ÄúAn Unmarried Woman‚Äù so remarkable and even groundbreaking today. But just imagine that take in the 1970s, barely a few years into Women‚Äôs Liberation. ‚ÄîRL In the cinema of Jean-Marie Straub and Dani√®le Huillet, ‚ÄúThe body keeps the score‚Äù is as true of the Earth itself as any human who trods upon it. Wielding a style of punishing austerity achieved through meticulous composition, movement, and editing, the filmmakers arrived at a singular meeting point between the classicism of John Ford and Charlie Chaplin and the avant-garde modernism of Robert Bresson and Bertolt Brecht. ‚ÄúFrom the Clouds to the Resistance‚Äù is one of the finest displays of their oeuvre, a testament to human struggle against oppressors ranging from ancient Greco-Roman myths of defying the gods all the way up to the antifascist resistances of the 1940s. Beneath its deliberately anti-dramatic surface of long takes and unemotional delivery of declamatory dialogue, the film communicates with lyrical beauty. Tree branches are used as proscenia to theatrically encase actors, and eyeline matches subtly establish power dynamics between their characters. Small fluctuations in natural light hint at shifts in those dynamics as one person or another asserts will against the other, and multi-planar compositions of landscape evoke painters like C√©zanne while also silently testifying to the incalculable gallons of blood spilled on hills and dales over the course of human history and its endless wars. And for all the filmmakers‚Äô Brechtian distance, they ultimately present a deeply human thesis of the capacity to endure and oppose even the harshest regimes of control. ‚ÄîJC Politically incisive director Lindsay Anderson found in Malcolm McDowell a wide-eyed and peculiar vessel to examine the economic inequities and ideologically corrosive nature of post-war British capitalism. Here, in the picaresque second film of their Mick Travis trilogy, McDowell embodies the perpetually cheerful lad as a coffee seller whose ambition and disposition earns him a rare upward mobility. As Mick travels across the U.K.‚Äôs northeast selling his unethically sourced product, his quick ascent and eventual downfall is interspersed with Alan Price‚Äôs musical performances. With lyrics like ‚ÄúSell everything you stand for‚Äù or ‚ÄúSomeone‚Äôs got to win in the human race/ If it isn‚Äôt you, then it has to be me,‚Äù the tracks are far from conspicuous, but their inclusion lends a cheeky undertone to a film that‚Äôs brimming with latent darkness. Anderson and screenwriter David Sherwin insert Travis‚Äô evolution from idealism to disillusionment into the larger context of the Britain‚Äôs blood-soaked imperial past and its enduring consequences. As Travis becomes aware he‚Äôs just a disposable pawn, susceptible and perhaps even powerless to the whims of a system designed to chew him up and spit him out, McDowell‚Äôs expression turns from curious to utterly defeated. The character‚Äôs ‚Äúluck‚Äù has ultimately run out. ‚ÄîCA Chris Marker‚Äôs three-hour cin√©-essay takes a look over the preceding decade of global leftist movements and their various failures, from the student protests across the west to pushes in Soviet states for greater autonomy from Moscow. It is the latter that often proves the most compelling material for how little it has been covered in the west; in one of the film‚Äôs most transfixing sequences, Marker plays footage of Fidel Castro publicly declaring support for the Soviet Union‚Äôs invasion of Czechoslovakia to repress protests, lingering on the Cuban leader‚Äôs ambiguous expression for hints of self-awareness at betraying the higher ideals of revolution for self-determination. Marker‚Äôs pioneering form of half-studious, half-associative history has arguably become more relevant in recent years than it ever was during his lifetime, a clear forerunner to an entire genre of video content devoted to obsessive exegeses of politics and pop culture. Adam Curtis in particular is inconceivable without this film, but Marker‚Äôs overriding sense of play avoids the pitfalls of conspiratorial frenzy that besets so many of his successors. ‚ÄîJC Lino Brocka‚Äôs 1975 genre-bending fable is so dexterous an affair that you‚Äôd be forgiven for accidentally underselling it. It is a queer melodrama, a sociological survey of Marcos-era Filipino life, and a rollicking mystery. Without ever dulling the film‚Äôs gritty, anti-colonialist messaging, ‚ÄúManila in the Claws of Light‚Äù remains prime entertainment. It feels miraculous that the film even exists in the first place ‚Äî that Brocka did this, in front of a camera, with this many people, that it looks this good, and that it released to international success. Yet none of the aforementioned qualities are what lingers most vividly between individual viewings. The most striking aspect of the film is the infrastructure: The dirt piles next to a construction site, the market stalls built from sheet metal, the hand-painted menus at a restaurant. Brocka‚Äôs camera focuses so intently on these spaces because of he cares so passionately for the people whose spirit threaten to be crushed by merely inhabiting them. When I think about ‚ÄúManila in the Claws of Light,‚Äù this is what first comes to mind. ‚ÄîSB In 1973, the Japanese equivalent of Walt Disney decided to adapt a 19th century book about the feminist history of witchcraft into an animated prog-rock musical about a medieval peasant girl who gets gang-raped on her wedding night and then turns to Satan for help with her revenge. This is really a thing that happened. See it even once and you‚Äôll never forget that it did. Strange even by the psychedelic standards of its time, Eiichi Yamamoto‚Äôs wild and exhausting ‚ÄúBelladonna of Sadness‚Äù is a sinister anime fairytale inspired by the same fetish for medievalism that gripped Jacques Demy and Pier Paolo Pasolini, layered in recursive prog-rock jams, and filled with enough vaginal imagery to make Georgia O‚ÄôKeeffe blush. From that imagery erupts the film‚Äôs vivid approach to sexual violence, as the heroine‚Äôs assault is symbolized by the sight of her naked body being cleaved in two down the middle like a butchered animal carcass, blood flying out of wound in the form of bats that flap off into oblivion. Few movies have ever so viscerally depicted the psychic toll of such trauma ‚Äî the crime‚Äôs power to tear a person apart from themselves. Smarter than it is salacious, the film‚Äôs narrative complements its Eurocentric art style, further distancing ‚ÄúBelladonna of Sadness‚Äù from the world of hentai and locating it instead in a Western history where women are positioned as angels of liberty, and witchcraft their way of rebelling against institutional misogyny. History has a habit of prizing women for their sexuality one minute and punishing them for it the next, and Yamamoto‚Äôs film reflects that dynamic down to its core. This is a story about men who are in the thrall of a woman‚Äôs beauty, and then enraged by their inability to control it. It continues to prove moving, even in its (budget-enforced) stillness. ‚ÄîDE A tumbleweed-like tour across a broken country that‚Äôs trying to get back on its feet as the horrors of the Vietnam War come to a close, Jerry Schatzberg‚Äôs painfully unforgiving ‚ÄúScarecrow‚Äù is a story about two drifters who give each other a sense of direction even though neither of them has anywhere left to go. Max Millan (Gene Hackman) is a short-tempered ex-con who looks askance at everyone he meets. Frances Lionel ‚ÄúLion‚Äù Delbuchi (Al Pacino) is a stunted and guileless former sailor who dreams of reconnecting with his ex in Pittsburgh ‚Äî and of becoming a father to the child he‚Äôs never met. These odd vagabonds make for a strained and unlikely pair of friends, but Lion‚Äôs puppy dog naivete turns out to be the perfect counterweight to Max‚Äôs cynicism, and it isn‚Äôt long before these two men are supporting each other in a way that no one else ever has. Shadowed by a deep and implacable darkness from the moment it starts, ‚ÄúScarecrow‚Äù endures ‚Äî and even offers its own strange kind of comfort ‚Äî because of the lightning-in-a-bottle frisson it captures between its lead characters, whose tetchy dynamic was reflected in the conflicting styles of the actors who played them. Hackman‚Äôs introspective reserve clashed with Pacino‚Äôs method immersion, and though both actors were at the height of their powers, it took all of their combined talent to make it through a scene without snapping. That barely contained explosiveness lends an extra poignancy to the strength that Max and Lion give to and take from each other; it builds and builds until the point where their friendship starts to seem like it could point towards true north in a world that‚Äôs lost its moral compass. Alas, it leads them somewhere else in the end, as ‚ÄúScarecrow‚Äù resolves as an indelibly American reminder that moving forward isn‚Äôt as simple as finding a way to get there. ‚ÄîDE Robert Bresson shook up his image as an imposing, aesthetically spartan moralist ‚ÄúFour Nights of a Dreamer,‚Äù which unmoors his usually materialist cinema into the realm of fantasia. Inspired by Dostoevsky‚Äôs short story, ‚ÄúWhite Nights,‚Äù the film follows the relationship that forms between a suicidal young woman and the stranger who attempts to convince her to live. Bresson retains his economy of storytelling to capture the caution with which both people open up to each other, but elsewhere he indulges in the most delicate and effervescent camera work of his career. At times, the film verges on comedy, if not outright self-parody. In a brief film-within-the-film moment, Bresson renders the bare plot as a quasi-thriller as if to show he could make more traditionally crowd-pleasing fare if he wished, and he reworks the ending of the source story as a bleakly funny punchline on the smitten protagonist‚Äôs presumption of possible romance with his rescued damsel. And yet, the underlying interest of Bresson‚Äôs filmography ‚Äî the elusive search for truth in any of its forms ‚Äî is as present here as his more feted works. For Bresson, the ‚Äúmeet-cute‚Äù becomes a means of unpacking the entire spiritual possibilities of love. ‚ÄîJC When talking about ‚Äò70s culture, words like ‚Äúparanoid‚Äù and ‚Äúanti-establishment‚Äù loom so heavily in the air that it‚Äôs easy to lose sight of their meaning and use them exclusively as aesthetic descriptors. But even after 50 years, a film like ‚ÄúDog Day Afternoon‚Äù makes it impossible to reduce the social unrest it depicts to grooming choices and editing styles. No amount of philosophizing disgrace and criticizing fears could convince a viewer that the society Sydney Lumet depicts isn‚Äôt on the brink of collapse ‚Äî or, at the very least, isn‚Äôt convinced of its own imminent downfall. Even by the comparably low standards of the antihero-loving ‚Äò70s, Sonny Worzik is not the kind of hero that a healthy civilization turns its eyes to in times of need. A chaos agent with all the poise of a chainsaw juggler in their first day on the job, his impulsive bank robbery devolves into a hostage situation in the blink of an eye. Fueled by little more than a deep belief that nobody‚Äôs promises are worth the paper they‚Äôre printed on, his make-things-up-as-he-goes approach to negotiation is the work of a man who feels so utterly invisible that he‚Äôll settle for making enough noise to be noticed. On a technical narrative level, ‚ÄúDog Day Afternoon‚Äù is as gripping a thriller as they come. As a social artifact, it‚Äôs one of the definitive examples of the chaos that was seeping into every crack of the American consciousness. Sonny only gains momentum from his admirers as he invokes the Attica prison riots, cultivating the crowd‚Äôs anger into a collective demand to see someone, anyone, do something to upset the powers that be. It‚Äôs all futile, as there‚Äôs only one way that a movie like this can end, but few films have ever reflected that futility with so much fire. ‚ÄîCZ Nicolas Roeg‚Äôs ‚ÄúWalkabout‚Äù was only the British director‚Äôs second feature after 1970‚Äôs ‚ÄúPerformance‚Äù heralded him as an independent moviemaker to watch ‚Äî and one with a special predilection for unique cross-cutting that felt like a fascinating new riff on the French New Wave. With one of the decade‚Äôs most indelible prologues, his film thrusts us into the arid wilds of the Australian Outback, where two English schoolchildren (played by Jenny Agutter and Luc Roeg, the director‚Äôs son) are unceremoniously dumped by their depressed father after he tries to kill them, and only ends up killing himself. At the same time, their paths as they try to survive in the desert collide with a Black Aboriginal boy (David Gulpilil, who went on to have a huge film career of his own after this breakout debut) who is on the rite-of-passage journey of which the title gets its name. Still streaked by Roeg‚Äôs nihilistic worldview despite the potentially heartwarming center, the unsentimental and briskly told ‚ÄúWalkabout‚Äù is also a brutal and unsparing portrait of survival in the wilderness. And speaking of cross-cutting, it‚Äôs perhaps most famous for a scene in which Agutter is seen swimming naked, juxtaposed against Gulpilil mercilessly hunting down Outback wildlife. ‚ÄúWalkabout‚Äù is a movie all about juxtapositions ‚Äî man vs. nature, the modern vs. the ancient, the landscape vs. the colonial human forces cutting into and against it. But the tenuous bond that forms between the siblings and the boy, who doesn‚Äôt speak a lick of the English language, suggests in cinematic terms how those opposing forces ultimately could (and should) coexist. ‚ÄîRL Akio Jissoji careened from the populist Japanese TV of ‚ÄúUltraman‚Äù to the heights of the nation‚Äôs avant-garde with this, the first of a trio of films inspired by Buddhist philosophy. Setting up a morality play in which a monastery attempts to intervene in a local case of youthful sexual indiscretion prove disastrous, the film pivots almost instantly into an abstract self-examination of human contradictions that mingles Middle Path precepts with Marxist dialectics. Not unlike the films of John Cassavetes, ‚ÄúThis Transient Life‚Äù uses manic theatricality as a means of unpacking subtle emotional complexity, finding grounded and relatable foibles in garish extremes. Throughout, Jissoji puts his camera everywhere except where you‚Äôd expect it to be, capturing the drama in de-centered, wide-angled frames that only exacerbate the feeling of the characters being distorted and magnified for study. Rarely has the notion of characters being put under a microscope felt more literally true. ‚ÄîJC Barbet Schroeder‚Äôs remarkable documentary was billed as a ‚Äúself-portrait‚Äù for good reason. Uganda‚Äôs brutally despotic then-president, Idi Amin, agreed to be filmed on his own terms, confident in how he wanted to be seen. Schroeder let him perform for the camera with minimal intervention, which represented a seismic directorial choice unto itself. ‚ÄúGeneral Idi Amin Dada: A Self-Portrait‚Äù doesn‚Äôt analyze Amin‚Äôs power ‚Äî it lets us see how power presents itself. What results is both document and spectacle: a record of one man‚Äôs delusion, and a warning about how easily image can replace truth. Nearly 50 years later, it still disturbs by showing what happens when control of the camera becomes part of the performance. ‚ÄîTO Akira Kurosawa was so disheartened by the failure of 1970‚Äôs Gorky-esque ‚ÄúDodes‚Äôka-den‚Äù that he tried taking his own life. Despite surviving the attempt, Kurosawa was still resigned to the fact that he was unlikely to receive funding ever again. So when the 63-year-old auteur was approached by the Soviet film studio Mosfilm to spend almost two years in the taiga adapting Vladimir Arsenyev‚Äôs epic novel ‚ÄúDersu Uzala‚Äù (a book that he had supposedly been fascinated by since the earliest days of his career), Kurosawa wasn‚Äôt exactly in a position to say no. The resulting film turned a profit, won an Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film, and allowed the ‚ÄúSeven Samurai‚Äù director to keep working for another 18 years ‚Äî a period that saw the creation of the late-career masterpieces ‚ÄúKagemusha‚Äù and ‚ÄúRan.‚Äù But here‚Äôs the thing: ‚ÄúDersu Uzala‚Äù is as great as those films ‚Äî as raw and ravishing as anything Kurosawa ever made. Nature had always played an ambient role in his films, but here, in the story of a czarist expedition to the extremes of Russia‚Äôs Far East in the early 20th century, it would become the director‚Äôs primary subject. The heart of the story is the growing friendship between the leader of the expedition and a Goldi (or Nanai) hunter named Dersu Uzala who serves as their guide. A number of set pieces stand out, most of all the wildfire that consumes a wheat field, which is given extra dimension by the faded otherworldliness of SovColor ‚Äî Kurosawa would later pay more explicit tribute to Van Gogh in ‚ÄúDreams,‚Äù but this is the movie of his that most resembles one of the Dutch master‚Äôs paintings. A committed leftist his whole life, Kurosawa also found in this story one of cinema‚Äôs most profound explorations of colonialism and the impossibility of indigenous people continuing their way of life untrammeled by imperial forces. The animist Goldi believe that nothing can truly be owned, that everything living has a spirit, whereas the Russian forces maintain that everything can quantified and acquired. The tragedy sparked from those two conflicting perspectives is every bit as haunting today as it was 50 years ago. ‚ÄîCB The ‚Äò70s were the decade when cinema was formally established as a field worthy of academic study, and one of the things that was regularly discussed in university film classes was the attempt at finding ‚Äúa new language for film.‚Äù Traditionalist Luchino Visconti was in pursuit of the same with his adaptation of Thomas Mann‚Äôs ‚ÄúDeath in Venice,‚Äù which sees newly widowed Mahler stand-in Gustav von Aschenbach journey to the Lido for ‚Äúabsolute rest.‚Äù As Dirk Bogarde‚Äôs ailing composer silently takes in the sights on his Italian vacation, Visconti delivers a portrait of subjectivity as potent as ‚ÄúRear Window,‚Äù and with similarly radical sound design. Dialogue seamlessly overlaps with ambient noise as Gustav quietly observes the world against his ever-diminishing place in it, but that languid sense of despair is soon interrupted by the sight of Tadzio (Bjorn Andresen), a beautiful Polish teenager who becomes Gustav‚Äôs all-consuming obsession. Is Gustav‚Äôs fixation predatory, or is it simply that the boy personifies the lost possibilities of the older man‚Äôs life? Something to puzzle over. Until that central relationship is established (for his part, Tadzio barely notices the existence of Gustav at all), ‚ÄúDeath in Venice‚Äù is comfortable to exist in the liminal space between the gorgeousness of its setting and the dread of its protagonist‚Äôs anxiety. It‚Äôs filmmaking to get lost in, and the ultimate apotheosis of Italian cinema‚Äôs inward shift away from Fellini-esque expressionism. Taken in the context of Visconti‚Äôs filmography, ‚ÄúDeath in Venice‚Äù feels like a radical departure from the operatic eruptions of ‚ÄúRocco and His Brothers.‚Äù It‚Äôs a film where slight glances, whispered introductions, and the silent offer of an outstretched hand are rich enough to signify the world entire. ‚ÄîCB Made fearlessly just a few years after the 1968 student protests in Mexico City, which resulted in numerous deaths at the hands of the government, Felipe Cazals‚Äô searing indictment of how propaganda can incite a herd mentality ‚Äî and result in deadly violence ‚Äî remains as potent as it was when first released. The pioneering filmmaker structured his defiant narrative partially as a fake documentary featuring interviews with actors playing residents of the small rural town of San Miguel Canoa. Their accounts often clash with what we learn happened one night after the malevolent local priest, played with chilling nonchalance by Enrique Lucero, convinces the impoverished residents that a group of young men forced to stay the night in town due to torrential rain are students who‚Äôve arrived to threaten their faith. Without proof of these claims other than the word from the man of the cloth (who operates with ulterior motives), the virulent mob unleash brutality on the visitors ‚Äî who are in fact university workers, and not pupils. A cautionary tale about the perils of pervasive repression, ‚ÄúCanoa‚Äù endures as one of the darkest and most knowing films of its kind. ‚ÄîCA The complaint that they don‚Äôt make movies like they used to is as cliched as it is eternal, but watching ‚ÄúThe Heartbreak Kid‚Äù in 2025 is a quick way to remind yourself how true it really is. The existence of a major studio release centered around a reprehensible man who starts an affair on his honeymoon ‚Äî and then proceeds to meander through a slow-paced journey in which he learns nothing before the movie fizzles out with a whimper ‚Äî would be unthinkable in any era except the New Hollywood of the 1970s. And yet, anyone lucky enough to track down a copy of this semi-lost classic can attest that it still holds up as one of the driest, funniest movies of the 20th century. Charles Grodin‚Äôs Lenny Cantrow is a man without a single redeeming quality, a smarmy sporting goods salesman who radiates so much selfishness that every institution holding polite society together seemingly dissolves in his presence. To be fair, nobody around him is that great either. His first wife Lila (Jeannie Berlin) is hopelessly naive and needy, falling for Lenny‚Äôs tricks for far longer than she should, even if their relationship barely lasts a week. And his second target, Cybill Shepherd‚Äôs Kelly Corcoran (because of course, a girl like that would have a name like Kelly Corcoran), is all too happy to let a newlywed man pursue her, seemingly only for the fleeting pleasure of the attention he provides. The only character with any redeeming qualities is her overbearing father who forbids her from dating Lenny. He‚Äôs the kind of cheap stock character who normally serves as an antagonist to be defeated in most romances, but the only person thinking clearly in this sick sad world, which should tell you everything you need to know about the morality we‚Äôre dealing with here.The all-star pairing of writer Neil Simon and director Elaine May renders the story with an appropriately unsympathetic gaze. Lenny barrels through the world spewing self-serving bullshit as he chases shiny object after shiny object, hurting everyone in his path who falls for it and leaving the few outsiders who see through him to shake their heads in disgust. ‚ÄúThe Heartbreak Kid‚Äù is often labeled a satire of marriage, but that‚Äôs only a half-truth. May and Simon take a neutral stance on the practice itself, but make it clear that some of us are far too narcissistic to deserve it. And the film‚Äôs brilliantly abrupt ending illustrates that there‚Äôs no other institution that could successfully take its place, because the real problems lie within us, not the cauliflower. ‚ÄîCZ It‚Äôs hard to argue that Lau Kar Leung‚Äôs ‚ÄúHeroes of the East‚Äù is the best of the Shaw Brothers classics that came out of Hong Kong during the 1970s, as the decade‚Äôs ‚Äî and the century‚Äôs ‚Äî quintessential martial-arts studio simply produced too many immortal beat-em-ups for there to be a definitive standout. Nevertheless, this ultra-kinetic relationship comedy about the arranged marriage between a rich Chinese kung fu student (the great Gordon Liu as Ho Tao) and a deceptively meek Japanese woman (Yuka Mizuno as Yumiko) serves as the perfect stand-in for an entire golden age on a list like this one. Not only does ‚ÄúHeroes of the East‚Äù highlight a wide, wide variety of the fighting styles that were showcased across the Shaw Brothers‚Äô filmography, and not only does it provide the most dynamic showcase for one of the studio‚Äôs greatest stars, but it also epitomizes how fluently these movies bent combat into a hyper-eloquent form of communication unto itself. In this case, that communication expresses a fierce cross-cultural rivalry between Chinese and Japanese styles ‚Äî comedically at first, and then with growing intensity as a legion of masters from the land of the rising sun travel to Shanghai to prove that Ho Tao is unworthy of Yumiko‚Äôs hand. Scored by a symphony of chop! pow! sound effects, each duel is a discrete masterpiece of old school kung-fu choreography, and they build on one another in a way that turns the entire second half of the movie into an extended crescendo of balletic ass-kicking, the grand finale of which is made all the more satisfying by the respect Lau pays to both of the countries involved. ‚ÄîDE Ousmane Semb√®ne‚Äôs ‚ÄúCeddo‚Äù offers a vivid and exceptionally complex look at the nascent days of Senegal‚Äôs European colonization, but the actual time period covered by the events of the film is never firmly established. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt give a date,‚Äù Semb√®ne said when presented the question. ‚ÄúThese events occurred in the 18th and 19th century, and are still occurring.‚Äù A Wolof-speaking people face a crossroads: Their king wants to ally with the Islamic forces that have been exerting a growing influence on their country, which would later become the modern-day nation of Senegal. The ‚ÄúCeddo,‚Äù outsiders who refuse to be colonized by either Muslims or Christians, kidnap the king‚Äôs daughter as ransom to ensure that he turns away from Islam. Violence ensues. Western cinema is prone to stories of privileged male characters being marooned with their enemies, only to find shared values and common cause along the way. With history on its side, ‚ÄúCeddo‚Äù inverts that hero‚Äôs journey, as it‚Äôs the king‚Äôs daughter Dior (Tabata Ndiaye) who finds a new perspective among the outsiders and ultimately fights against her father ‚Äî a painful but rousing struggle that highlights the eternal war against cultural usurpation, and the crucial role that women must be allowed to play in that fight. ‚ÄîCB A soft but sexually charged drama against the stunning alpine backdrop of Lake Annecy over the course of a summer month, √âric Rohmer‚Äôs ‚ÄúClaire‚Äôs Knee‚Äù initially resembles what a hater of French arthouse cinema probably thinks all of the nation‚Äôs films are about. Its story tells of a middle-aged man named J√©r√¥me (Jean-Claude Brialy) whose recent engagement has done nothing to slow his lust for other women. He develops a romantic interest in two underage girls as part of what can only be described an esoteric wager he makes while discussing sex and monogamy with a novelist friend (Aurora Cornu). When he learns that the younger of the two girls is in love with him, he makes a move on her out of recreation as much as anything else, only to be shot down because she doesn‚Äôt believe he truly loves her. He then turns his attention to her step-sister, forming an obsession with her knee that consumes his thoughts. But no plot summaries could ever hope to do the film justice, as ‚ÄúClaire‚Äôs Knee‚Äù has less to do with any individual human relationship than our remarkable ability to rationalize our desires and misdeeds. J√©r√¥me never gets a chance to consummate his lust for Claire ‚Äî nor, it could be argued, does he really want to. Instead, Rohmer masterfully illustrates the way possession and attainability (or the lack thereof) are inextricably tied to our desires. Every interaction is so profoundly overanalyzed and overcomplicated that it‚Äôs a miracle anyone has any fun at all on this miserable trip. The real lesson might be that when there‚Äôs a void of activity on a summer vacation, humans will naturally move to fill it. The lewd premise builds to the most chaste of climaxes, with J√©r√¥me talking himself into being content with an utterly mundane (if sinisterly motivated) interaction. Because, despite all of its stunning scenery, ‚ÄúClaire‚Äôs Knee‚Äù is a film that takes place entirely inside its characters‚Äô minds, with the mental gymnastics they perform to assign meaning to all of their endeavors taking precedence over the endeavors themselves. It‚Äôs one of the finest examples of Rohmer‚Äôs brand of cinema about destructively intellectual characters, and stands alongside ‚ÄúMy Night at Maud‚Äôs‚Äù as one of his finest ‚ÄúMoral Tales.‚Äù ‚ÄîCZ Rainer Werner Fassbinder left behind a body of work that struck a precarious yet remarkably sturdy balance of experimental theater, postwar radicalism, and classical Hollywood melodrama, and ‚ÄúAli: Fear Eats the Soul‚Äù is one of the great showcases of his malleability. Reworking the age-gap romantic yearning of Douglas Sirk‚Äôs ‚ÄúAll That Heaven Allows‚Äù around the additional complication of race, Fassbinder brings together lonely, widowed empty-nester Emmi (Brigitte Mira) and hale young Moroccan immigrant Ali (El Hedi ben Salem) as an unlikely couple who rapidly developing affection faces constant tests from disapproving friends, relatives, and sneering passers-by. Fassbinder filters Sirk‚Äôs florid, intimate approach to melodrama through his own eerily pristine, at times ironically detached style. He frequently lenses in long shots that convey not the emotions between the couple but the icy, judgmental stares of others who watch them with revulsion. The film also highlights the way in which even the most obviously disapproving people will still put on a facade of cordiality that only makes their disdain sharper. There are also reminders of Germany‚Äôs grim recent history, as when Emmi takes Ali to an upscale restaurant to celebrate their elopement and reflexively boasts ‚ÄúHitler used to eat here!‚Äù As both she and Ali feel the pressure from their loved ones to end their relationship, the emotions held at arm‚Äôs length eventually explode, leading to perhaps the most visceral ending of Fassbinder‚Äôs vast canon. ‚ÄîJC An obstinate seeker who hadn‚Äôt been able to finish any of the films he‚Äôd started, Errol Morris was on the verge of turning 30 when he stumbled upon a San Francisco Chronicle headline that read: ‚Äú450 DEAD PETS GOING TO NAPA VALLEY.‚Äù Armed with new resolve, he gathered money from friends and family to closely investigate the story in the spring and summer of 1977. His friend, Werner Herzog, famously pledged to eat a shoe if the film was ever finished and exhibited. Though it technically explores pet cemeteries, ‚ÄúGates of Heaven‚Äù isn‚Äôt much considered with its ostensible raison d‚Äô√™tre. Morris uses pets, death, and small businesses as a lens to consider people‚Äôs voices: the manner in which they speak, the narratives they construct about themselves, the yarns they spin. The young director bent cinema v√©rit√© to his will by eschewing the de rigueur handheld style of the era in favor of a static camera and direct address. Morris‚Äôs locked-off medium shots not only called attention to his highly composed framing, but they also had the hypnotic effect of drawing audiences closer to his subjects as they wax (or drawl) poetic (or comical) about everything under the sun. When Morris screened ‚ÄúGates of Heaven‚Äù for his idol Douglas Sirk at the Berlin Film Festival, he walked out halfway through, calling the film a slideshow. It‚Äôs easy to see how he arrived at such a conclusion, and, possibly heeding the filmmaker‚Äôs criticism, Morris would never deploy such stillness again in his career. But only the most stubbornly dogmatic viewer could ignore the cinematic spirit animating the director‚Äôs photographic compositions. Sirk also cautioned Morris about his film‚Äôs supposedly ironic pose, a humorous note considering how frequently the master of melodrama utilized irony in his own work. While Morris certainly mines comedy from his subjects‚Äôs eccentricities or quirks of speech, anyone who believes that he made ‚ÄúGates of Heaven‚Äù as an exercise in mockery simply isn‚Äôt paying attention. Morris‚Äôs permissive interviewing strategy, which entails getting his subjects to speak for as long as possible without much intervention, doesn‚Äôt merely facilitate open communication. It‚Äôs also a sign of unencumbered respect for their worldviews. Take, for example, Florence Rasmussen, an elderly woman who lives across the street from one of the two pet cemeteries the film examines. She delivers an uninterrupted five-minute monologue about her life while sitting in her front doorway. Circuitous and contradictory, and gloriously ‚Äúoff topic,‚Äù her speech exemplifies Morris‚Äôs attentive approach: if you just let people talk, they‚Äôll reveal the world. ‚ÄîVM A father has raised his children without contact with the outside world, and their lifelong isolation has warped their understanding of social norms. Yet the older they get, the more they question what‚Äôs beyond the walls that ostensibly cage them for their protection. The description may call to mind Yorgos Lanthimos‚Äô Oscar-nominated ‚ÄúDogtooth,‚Äù but it refers instead to ‚ÄúThe Castle of Purity,‚Äù the breakthrough film by unsung Mexican master Arturo Ripstein. Inspired by a shocking case that came to light in 1950s Mexico City, the unflinching drama chronicles how Gabriel (Claudio Brook), a disturbed patriarch, walks the streets finding buyers for the rat poison that his wife and kids produce in their large home. He rules with the firm hand of an authoritarian at home, and though he forbids his family from eating meat or indulging in worldly vices, he doesn‚Äôt preach by example. Ripstein, who immediately recognized the inspiration that ‚ÄúDogtooth‚Äù took from his film, is an artist recurrently interested in religious hypocrisy and the most sordid alcoves of the human mind; here, he depicts the abuse Gabriel inflicts on his household with sobering rigor, resolving in an unforgettable study of how evil has always found domesticity to be among its most convincing disguises. ‚ÄîCA A 15-year-old moppet named Mike (John Moulder-Brown) drops out of school and lands a gig at an East London public bath at the tail end of the swingin‚Äô ‚Äô60s, where he‚Äôs preyed upon by the sexually underserved female clientele at the same time as he begins obsessing over his seasoned and inscrutable co-worker Susan (Jane Asher, fresh off a relationship with Paul McCartney). It‚Äôs Mike‚Äôs first job, and he doesn‚Äôt know that they‚Äôre not all like this. Plunged into a seedy but spectacular world that‚Äôs brimming with desire and steeped in confusion, Mike is soon at the mercy of his own lust for life ‚Äî a lust that fixates upon Susan, and rages at all the reasons why she can‚Äôt belong to him. One of the only color movies that David Lynch ever loved, Jerzy Skolomowski‚Äôs darkly fun ‚ÄúDeep End‚Äù is as hyper-vivid in its production design as it is in its hormonal distress. Here is a film that sees coming of age as a delirium thick enough to drown in, as its naive protagonist ‚Äî a virginal need monster who sees older men take what they want from the young women around them, and is too horny to recognize that they‚Äôre stealing ‚Äî tries his best to stay afloat in the turbulent waters between free love and possessive ownership. Skolomowski‚Äôs almost psychedelic approach to psychosexual mania creates an unbroken dreamstate where nothing feels real but everything is. Where the world begs to be touched even as it remains just out of reach. Where Susan is both an inanimate crush object and a richly humanized character who‚Äôs already had to pay too high a price for her sexual currency (a dynamic that‚Äôs indelibly realized in the sequence where Mike steals a life-sized nude cut-out of a woman who looks just like Susan, and proceeds to project all of his desire onto it over the course of a long dark night). All the more true to life for its expressionistic flourishes, and for an ending that feels like it was ripped from the pages of a fable, ‚ÄúDeep End‚Äù announced the full possibilities of ‚Äô70s cinema with a fatal bang. ‚ÄîDE Widely acknowledged as the first home-grown Jamaican film to be shot with an entirely Jamaican cast and crew, Perry Henzell‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Harder They Come‚Äù is a shaggy-dog thriller that also happens to be a form-breaking smash (as radical as ‚ÄúBreathless‚Äù in its own right), and ‚Äúthe film that brought reggae to the world.‚Äù That‚Äôs the thing: Maybe you‚Äôve never watched ‚ÄúThe Harder They Come,‚Äù but you‚Äôve absolutely heard multiple songs from its smash-hit soundtrack album. Many of them are by the film‚Äôs star Jimmy Cliff, but the tunes also include all-time bangers like ‚ÄúDraw Your Brakes‚Äù by Scotty and ‚ÄúSweet and Dandy‚Äù and ‚ÄúPressure Drop‚Äù by Toots & the Maytals. Take a look at the movie, though: Cliff stars as a wayward youth, Ivanhoe ‚ÄúIvan‚Äù Martin, who grew up in the countryside but tries to make it big in the Kingston recording industry. Crossing paths with gangsters and a shady record mogul who only wants to pay him a one-and-done $20 for recording the title track, Ivan becomes a trigger-happy outlaw unwilling to play by society‚Äôs rules. It starts naturalistically enough, so much so that if you just flipped to it on TV you might think it‚Äôs a documentary at first. By the end, however, Henzell‚Äôs film actually plays more like late ‚Äò60s Godard than ‚ÄúBreathless,‚Äù with scenes of militarized police pursuing Ivan on gorgeous beaches while meta touches ‚Äî including the interspersed use of Sergio Corbucci‚Äôs ‚ÄúDjango‚Äù ‚Äî break down why we‚Äôre all so besotted by outlaw mystique in the first place. Even if the music gets more of the attention, the film itself is every bit as intoxicating. If there‚Äôs the cinematic equivalent of an ear-worm, this is it. ‚ÄîCB Long before indie cinema as we know it found its footing in the ‚Äô90s, Claudia Weill‚Äôs ‚ÄúGirlfriends‚Äù delivered a groundbreaking look at female friendship, ambition, and loneliness ‚Äî all through the lens of one woman‚Äôs coming-of-age in New York City. Shot on a shoestring budget (and one that almost didn‚Äôt cut it), but with razor-sharp emotional clarity, ‚ÄúGirlfriends‚Äù is a landmark of American independent filmmaking and one of the most criminally overlooked gems of the 1970s. Well, overlooked no more. At a time when studio films rarely centered the interior lives of women, ‚ÄúGirlfriends‚Äù dared to tell a story about the complexities of female independence. Melanie Mayron stars as Susan, a struggling photographer navigating career uncertainty and emotional isolation after her best friend (played by Anita Skinner) abruptly gets married and moves out. What follows is a radical exploration of solitude, creative frustration, and the shifting dynamics of female friendship. Think of it this way, can you name another film that both Stanley Kubrick and Greta Gerwig have praised? Weill‚Äôs direction captures small moments with a documentary-like intimacy that feels years ahead of its time. There‚Äôs no melodrama here ‚Äî just the authentic messiness of life in your twenties, portrayed with empathy and humor. It‚Äôs a film that doesn‚Äôt just pass the Bechdel Test ‚Äî it practically wrote it. In an era dominated by antiheroes and epics, ‚ÄúGirlfriends‚Äù carved out something smaller, more personal ‚Äî and in doing so, became one of the most enduring and influential films of the decade. ‚ÄîKE Hayao Miyazaki is most famous for making personal, original, idiosyncratic films about his favored themes: nature, environmentalism, pacifism, feminism, youth, and aging. But for his feature debut, when Ghibli was just a glimmer in his eye, he made pure franchise popcorn entertainment. And the result is a complete blast. ‚ÄúThe Castle of Cagliostro‚Äù is a stand-alone entry in the ‚ÄúLupin III‚Äù series, an iconic manga and anime franchise about the descendant of legendary gentleman thief Arsene Lupin, as he travels the world with his criminal gang taking on heists and outfoxing the determined Interpol agent Zenigata. In ‚ÄúCastle of Cagliostro,‚Äù his heist isn‚Äôt to steal money or gold, but a person: Princess Clarisse, who is being forced to marry the titular Cagliostro, a monstrous greedy count. It‚Äôs a perfect setup for some fun, and ‚ÄúCastle of Cagliostro‚Äù is fun above all else, a total action-adventure blast with setpieces like the car chase and the often-imitated clock-tower fight that rank among the most thrilling moments in the anime film canon. Miyazaki‚Äôs confidence and skill as director from the jump is a sight to behold. ‚ÄîWC ‚ÄúThe Devils‚Äù is a blasphemous film, although the hysterical profanity and nuns lasciviously tonguing Christ‚Äôs side wound aren‚Äôt what‚Äôs truly heretical about it. Instead, director Ken Russell‚Äôs most vicious critiques of the Catholic Church appear in the small moments of spiritual repose playboy priest Father Grandier (Oliver Reed) finds with a woman he meets through the church. The Holy See‚Äôs perverse lust for power means that it would rather torture and kill innocent people than allow them to find God through each other. That‚Äôs what Russell‚Äôs condemning here. The rest is all set dressing ‚Äî set dressing provocative enough that Warner Bros. has done its best to suppress the film for the past 50 years, but still. ‚ÄîKR What is left to say about a film like ‚ÄúKlute?‚Äù Alan J. Pakula‚Äôs call girl noir has had, at one point or another, every element of its craft rightly celebrated by critics in the 54 years since its initial release. The textures of the film ‚Äî the score, the outfits, the light fixtures and how Gordon Willis painted with them ‚Äî prove the aesthetic zenith of a bygone era in American cinema. In a genre where individuals are often merely synecdoche for institutional machinations, the romance between Jane Fonda and Donald Sutherland is disarmingly grounded. Fonda‚Äôs Bree Daniel is an idol of feminist cinema, and the film‚Äôs radically non-judgmental view of sex work remains admirable. In a world so obsessed with the contradiction of cinematic voyeurism and the symbolic martyrdom of rough women, Pakula pursues different questions with better answers. ‚ÄúKlute‚Äù examines the sensuality of autonomy, the messiness of adult intimacy, and whether acting in direct defiance of harms suffered can ever offer real solace, or instead further trap someone within their trauma. All of this is well-worn territory, but none of that matters when you sit down to watch the movie ‚Äî even now, more than 50 years since ‚ÄúKlute‚Äù was first released, its allure proves totally singular. ‚ÄîSB Meiko Kaji was already bored with playing stoic badasses by the time she was approached for the title role in Toshiya Fujita‚Äôs adaptation of Kazuo Koike‚Äôs manga series. But she liked the director and the script, so she took the job. And thank goodness she did, because Kaji‚Äôs Yuki, an assassin trained from birth to avenge her family‚Äôs deaths, is one of the most iconic action heroines in all of cinema. Her graceful movements and intense stare are practically supernatural, an effect that‚Äôs enhanced by the striking production design and stylized carnage. You might think you‚Äôve seen the color red, but you really haven‚Äôt ‚Äî not until you‚Äôve seen ‚ÄúLady Snowblood.‚Äù ‚ÄîKR ‚ÄúWhy would you choose someone who loves you too little over someone who loves you too much?‚Äù Charles (John Heard) asks his lover Laura (Mary Beth Hurt) as they‚Äôre tearfully breaking up. ‚ÄúBecause it makes me feel less of a fraud,‚Äù she curtly responds. A toxically-romantic comedy adapted from Ann Beattie‚Äôs 1976 novel, Joan Micklin Silver‚Äôs ‚ÄúChilly Scenes of Winter‚Äù chronicles a doomed affair between two aimless thirtysomethings in snowy Salt Lake City. Charles pines for Laura in between wasting away at his bullshit government job and dealing with his mentally unstable mother (Gloria Grahame), but he does so to such an narcissistic, self-destructive degree that his behavior would raise significant red flags in our current social climate. Part of the greatness of ‚ÄúChilly Scenes of Winter‚Äù lies in Silver‚Äôs abject refusal to condemn Charles‚Äôs obsession with Laura; instead, she empathizes with his passion, even when he‚Äôs being pointedly unlikable or downright cruel. Heard‚Äôs holistic performance treats the romantic and spiteful streaks in Charles‚Äôs character as if they emanate from the same confused source rather than two sides of a split personality. His love is as genuine as Laura‚Äôs ambivalence, which extends in just about every direction ‚Äîtowards Charles and her failing marriage to her dull husband, but mostly towards herself. Silver‚Äôs sincere respect for the sheer realism of her characters‚Äîtheir messy personalities, the fundamentally tenebrous nature of their relationship, their asymmetrical love for each other‚Äîhas no parallel in the domestic drama. Yet, it‚Äôs Silver‚Äôs choice to situate Charles and Laura‚Äôs mutual anguish within, as opposed to outside, life‚Äôs myriad headaches that elevates their relationship to unexpected cinematic heights. Overfamiliar bosses and lovesick secretaries, familial burdens and friendly obligations, the humdrum routine of going to work and feeding oneself in winter intrude upon Charles‚Äôs heartache. Neither his lovelorn desires nor Laura‚Äôs guilt can take priority over everything else in their respective worlds because there‚Äôs simply too many unsexy adult responsibilities to manage, until eventually the yearning becomes another chore. Silver acutely understands that casual tragedy of Charles and Laura broken relationship is that life didn‚Äôt stop for them. It just goes on and on until the pain becomes a distant memory. ‚ÄîVM In her dismissive review of ‚ÄúSeven Beauties,‚Äù Pauline Kael wrote that Lina Wertm√ºller ‚Äúkeeps her films moving by hurling salamis at the audience.‚Äù And maybe that‚Äôs true ‚Äî after all, this withering dark comedy includes the most jarring close-up of a penis in the history of Holocaust cinema ‚Äî but not in the way that Kael meant it. By 1975, the movies were already starving for new ways to visualize the greatest atrocity of the 20th century, which three decades of post-war cinema had already ossified into a dead language of digestible images. Wertm√ºller had to feed the people something. In that sense, her magnum opus is one hell of a meal. A larger-than-life Giancarlo Giannini stars as Pasqualino ‚ÄúSeven Beauties‚Äù Frafuso, Naples‚Äô horniest and most flamboyant hoodlum, and a man whose utter lack of dignity is ultimately his only hope of enduring the depravity of a concentration camp. Combining the picaresque lightness of an old fable with the unfathomable horrors of real life ‚Äî and using the subversive pleasures of grindhouse cinema to reinvigorate a nightmare the world is always on the brink of forgetting ‚Äî Wertm√ºller‚Äôs greatest and most grotesque film had the temerity to think of survival as a virtue unto itself. In committing to that idea until the bitter end, ‚ÄúSeven Beauties‚Äù was able to prevent the Holocaust from becoming just another genre. Almost 50 years later, it still retains that same power. ‚ÄîDE A philosophical take on the vampire myth, Bill Gunn‚Äôs 1973 arthouse horror film features erudite characters, heady eroticism, and complex commentary on African-American ethnic and religious identity, all rendered in 16mm that shimmers in the summer heat. ‚ÄúNight of the Living Dead‚Äù actor Duane Jones stars, playing an anthropologist whose research into an obscure cult of African blood-drinkers gains a new dimension after his assistant (Gunn) stabs him with an ancient ceremonial dagger. It‚Äôs a startling work of art, one that was nearly lost after bad reviews led its distributor to recut it as an exploitation picture. Gunn‚Äôs version was eventually restored, and was remade by Spike Lee as ‚ÄúDa Sweet Blood of Jesus‚Äù in 2014. ‚ÄîKR Andrei Tarkovsky‚Äôs ‚ÄúStalker‚Äù looks and moves unlike anything that came before it. To create one of the most immersive sci-fi worlds ever captured on celluloid, Tarkovsky relied on the neat trick of telling audiences absolutely nothing. We never learn when the film takes place or what country its characters hail from, only that there‚Äôs a dangerous place called the Zone where you can come face to face with your truest desires. It‚Äôs a harrowing journey to your final destination, which requires those brave enough to visit the Zone to hire tour guides known as ‚ÄúStalkers.‚Äù That‚Äôs all we get before the Russian auteur launches us on an unforgettable journey through the contradictions of the human psyche. And it‚Äôs a good thing thing he keeps us in the dark so much, because anything else would be overkill.Tarkovsky fills the Zone with a combination of lush greenery and abandoned machinery, creating an undeniable image of humans fighting a losing battle with nature. Everything, from the tour guide‚Äôs warnings to the harsh landscape, suggests that mankind doesn‚Äôt belong here. That there are some truths lurking in the universe that we simply weren‚Äôt meant to know. It all builds to a climax that‚Äôs painful to wrap one‚Äôs mind around even after multiple viewings: Our truest desires are lurking so deep within us that there‚Äôs no guarantee that we know them ourselves. Tarkovsky was hardly the first to suggest that we‚Äôre imprisoned by our cravings and urges, but he crystallized their sinister and uncontrollable nature better than any filmmaker before or since. ‚ÄîCZ Martin Scorsese‚Äôs fourth feature showcased the director‚Äôs love for cinema ‚Äî and for the actresses who built it ‚Äî in its first frames. Shot by Marty‚Äôs pal Michael Ballhaus, this luminous 1974 drama kicks off with a nearly shot-for-shot homage to Victor Fleming‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Wizard of Oz‚Äù before opening up onto the world of Alice, played by Ellen Burstyn. Her delivery-driver husband, with whom she and her small son lived in a middle-of-nowhere New Mexico town, is killed on the job, and so they jettison to California in hopes of cobbling together a better life. Burstyn and Alfred Lutter, who plays Alice‚Äô son Tommy, have an easy chemistry; he‚Äôs a child who‚Äôs been around only adults his whole life and can‚Äôt relate to people his own age, forced to fathom the dramas and dealings of those older than him. Alice and Tommy wind up in Arizona, where she takes up a job at a folksy diner in hopes of scrounging up enough change to get all the way to California. Their time in Phoenix surrounds a lovely, leisurely plot where Alice gets into yet another bad relationship. Fabulous minor roles are played by the likes of Diane Ladd as another waitress at the cafe, who has an angry and witty tongue, and Jodie Foster as a tomboy Tommy later meets in Tucson. This and ‚ÄúMommy Dearest‚Äù were the only films screenwriter Robert Getchell was really known for. The gentle lilt and warmth of this kitchen-sink drama ‚Äî really the last from Scorsese ‚Äî make for a refreshing entree into the filmmaker‚Äôs meaner and more viscerally pungent later work. It‚Äôs the rare portrait of an intelligent and funny woman who stands on her own, even as she‚Äôs wobbling, in the director‚Äôs mostly male-driven filmography. For all the grief he‚Äôs gotten because of that slant, ‚ÄúAlice Doesn‚Äôt Live Here Anymore‚Äù remains one of the very best things he‚Äôs ever made. ‚ÄîRL No one could extract deep meaning from static landscapes like Chantal Akerman, and the ‚ÄúJeanne Dielman‚Äù filmmaker‚Äôs juxtaposition of avant-garde structure and raw emotion was never more potent than in ‚ÄúNews From Home.‚Äù In 1976, Akerman returned to New York City, where she lived for two years while finding her footing as an artist. There, she observed once-familiar settings made distant not only by time, but by the dispassionate lens of her camera. The resulting footage is overlaid with narration reading letters from Akerman‚Äôs mother, which are affectionate and chatty but with an undertone of sadness. Combined, they evoke a precise, poignant emotion, the lonely but thrilling sensation of standing on a train platform far from home. ‚ÄîKR It‚Äôs bold to make a thriller where the action is predicated on not moving around too much, and even bolder to remake the rare thriller that manages to pull that off (Henri-Georges Clouzot‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Wages of Fear‚Äù). But in the humid-as-hell ‚ÄúSorcerer,‚Äù William Friedkin‚Äôs direction turns the tiniest shifts into the stuff of breathtaking suspense, as two trucks ‚Äî doubled up to ensure that at least one of them makes the drop-off ‚Äî packed with highly unstable payloads of nitroglycerin slowly crawl their way through the muddy South American jungle. The roads that lead to these moments are almost as compelling, as Friedkin skillfully introduces the movie‚Äôs four criminal protagonists and their reasons for taking this suicidal job. Cynical, sweaty, and set to one of the most transportive film scores ever composed, ‚ÄúSorcerer‚Äù is New Hollywood filmmaking at its finest ‚Äî even if it took a few decades for Hollywood to realize it. ‚ÄîKR As sublime a full-color epic as has ever been projected onto a movie screen, King Hu‚Äôs ‚ÄúA Touch of Zen‚Äù was key in introducing the aesthetics and values of Chinese wuxia storytelling to the West. A former Shaw Brothers studio man with an artistic eye and an exacting sense of detail, Hu brought a spiritual dimension to his tales of chivalrous combat that elevated them above their contemporaries. Here, the martial-arts action is secondary: The first real fight scene doesn‚Äôt take place until nearly an hour into the picture. But when those scenes do come, they‚Äôre nothing short of spectacular ‚Äî balletic and graceful and edited with an eccentric rhythm that only enhances the magic of skilled performers in motion. ‚ÄîKR Made over an arduous 15 years in which star Meena Kumari‚Äôs alcoholism not only regularly derailed filming but ended her marriage to director Kamal Amrohi, ‚ÄúPakeezah‚Äù at last emerged in 1972 as a typically baroque Bollywood melodrama that traces a forbidden romance between a courtesan and her highborn lover down to the next generation of their respective families. Through various twists of fate, the daughter that a wealthy man could not recognize eventually catches the eye of his nephew, repeating a cycle of heartbreak. What separates the film from its peers is the sheer depth of Amrohi‚Äôs direction, which often makes up for Kumari‚Äôs inconsistent dancing in musical sequences with a heavy use of other performers arrayed in dizzying multi-planar compositions that cross the elaborate blocking of Jacques Tati‚Äôs ‚ÄúPlaytime‚Äù with the most ambitious Indian dance choreography. Rendered in luminous color, ‚ÄúPakeezah‚Äù is like an ornate music box, suspended outside of rationality or even time while conveying an instantly felt emotional directness. ‚ÄîJC Frederick Wiseman‚Äôs arc is one of the most important in the history of American documentary film: from a deep skeptic of U.S. institutions, to a fierce defender of them. ‚ÄúWelfare‚Äù is one of his greatest achievements because it occupies a kind of middle ground ‚Äî and points to exactly where America would be headed over the next 50 years. Set in a New York City welfare office, Wiseman‚Äôs film paints a portrait of American social assistance as existing in a kind of perpetual defensive posture. It consists almost entirely of deeply suspicious interviews between the welfare office workers and the struggling people they‚Äôre ostensibly there to help, as the workers almost never seem to trust the people who‚Äôve come in search of the assistance they need to survive. Each applicant who‚Äôs there to talk about a check that got lost in the mail or some other changed circumstance is kept at arm‚Äôs length with a verbal 10-foot pole, and subjected to a litany of questions that assume ill intent or ignorance of the office‚Äôs practices so profound that they don‚Äôt ‚Äúdeserve‚Äù help. This is 1975, just 10 years after the establishment of Great Society programs, but the Nixon-Ford push toward defunding these institutions is already underway. You can‚Äôt get rid of welfare and Medicaid altogether? Just make certain they‚Äôre so underfunded and understaffed they become hollowed out husks, their employees so overworked and undertrained that the people they are meant to help come to hate the very idea of government and are teed up to vote to dismantle it even further in the decades to come. Wiseman‚Äôs fly-on-the-wall approach relies upon luck and patience, and he captures lightning in a bottle with a particularly poetic welfare applicant who ends his film with a prophetic summation ‚Äî not only of his situation, but also of what it says about where America was headed. He suggests that if this country does so little to help its own people ‚Äî and make no mistake, this is a portrait of welfare as a system of loss and risk mitigation (with policing as a Band-Aid for everything) rather than one actually trying to help people and, you know, encourage a healthier, more productive, less aggrieved society ‚Äî America would cease to exist by 1988. It‚Äôs taken a bit longer than that, but his prediction is clearly in the process of coming true. ‚ÄúWelfare‚Äù isn‚Äôt only a lucid portrait of the past, it‚Äôs also Wiseman‚Äôs most prescient vision of the future. ‚ÄîCB Not only the greatest journalism movie ever made, ‚ÄúAll the President‚Äôs Men‚Äù is in some ways the ‚Äò70s movie par excellence, with its combination of an absolute naturalism in its acting and writing ‚Äî courtesy of an extraordinary script by William Goldman ‚Äî and a subtle expressionism in the cinematography by Gordon Willis. Goldman made an extraordinary choice: To only adapt the first half of Carl Bernstein and Bob Woodward‚Äôs book, ending the film with Nixon‚Äôs second inauguration in January 1973. It takes some of the melodrama out of the story of Watergate, and puts the focus squarely on the journalistic process. One thing is certain: ‚ÄúAll the President‚Äôs Men‚Äù features the greatest ‚Äúphone acting‚Äù of all time, with extremely lengthy scenes of Dustin Hoffman and Robert Redford‚Äôs Bernstein and Woodward speaking with source after source to assemble a journalistic puzzle for the ages. In Goldman‚Äôs hands, this is dialogue that‚Äôs purely procedural, full of pauses and filler words and dead ends (only a little of Bernstein and his girlfriend Nora Ephron‚Äôs script rewrite that established Bernstein as ‚Äúcatnip to the ladies,‚Äù according to Goldman, made it in), and brought to understated but never less than thrilling dramatic life by director Alan J. Pakula, with Redford overseeing the entire production through his Wildwood Enterprises company. As he had achieved in his previous films of his ‚ÄúParanoia Trilogy‚Äù (‚ÄúKlute‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Parallax View‚Äù), Pakula creates a pervasive mood of fear ‚Äî a fear that had threatened to become the animating force in American life. If anything, it turns out that we weren‚Äôt being paranoid enough. ‚ÄîCB Sometimes the smallest conflicts demand the largest canvases. Cinematographer Gordon Willis photographs New York City in black-and-white Panavision widescreen for ‚ÄúManhattan,‚Äù infusing the on-screen metropolis with timeless romantic grandeur. The city‚Äôs ineffable beauty lies in tension with the neuroses of Isaac Davis (director and co-writer Woody Allen), a twice-divorced middle-aged comedy writer juggling a relationship with seventeen-year-old high school student Tracy (Mariel Hemingway) and his growing attraction to cerebral journalist Mary (Diane Keaton), who‚Äôs having an affair with Isaac‚Äôs married best friend Yale (Michael Murphy). While Allen invests himself in the autogenous problems of the cultured class, he often throws them in sharp relief by situating them within the splendor of their urban environment. Manhattan streets become a playground for intellectual gamesmanship and emotional bonding. A conversation about past lovers and contemporary trysts takes place against the transcendental darkness of the Hayden Planetarium. Gramercy Park whizzes by in the background as a desperate man runs to save a doomed romance. They consume the city, but can‚Äôt lose themselves in it. Willis‚Äôs visual beauty neither elevates nor obscures the self-involved headaches of Allen‚Äôs characters. Instead, it envelops them, imbuing them with a cinematic gloss while keeping them firmly relegated to the mortal realm. The quotidian, narcissistic concerns at the heart of ‚ÄúManhattan‚Äù‚Äîtrying to find love and meaning at all personal costs, forgoing integrity for immediate pleasure, deferring mortality by throwing oneself into art ‚Äî still comprise the primordial goo of human experience. ‚ÄúYou have to have a little faith in people,‚Äù Tracy tells Isaac at the end of the film, after he uses her, mostly to torture himself, and then blithely tosses her aside for a shot at Mary, only to regret it the second he‚Äôs alone again. The famous line ‚Äî delivered impeccably by Hemingway, who gives a remarkably unaffected performance that still feels miraculous ‚Äî prompts a silent, powerfully uncertain reaction from Allen that can be read a million different ways. The cathartic Gershwin score underscores the irony of the moment‚Äôs superficially straightforward catharsis: Allen‚Äôs film argues people are predictable and disappointing, and that the only faith to be found in them is the consistency of their corruption. What‚Äôs left is art, which, of course, is made by people. If life is only worth living because of art, and art exists because of (or maybe in spite of) people, and people are inherently corrupt, then is life worth living? The ‚Äúunsolvable, terrifying problems of the universe‚Äù endure unabated. ‚ÄîVM At his core, Bobby Dupea is a searcher. Restless and irresolute, he‚Äôs determined to find purpose in a world that baffles him and amongst people who bore him. Born into an upper-class family of musical prodigies, Bobby rejects the comforts of his upbringing and his considerable artistic talents in favor of a hardscrabble blue-collar life. But it‚Äôs clear he doesn‚Äôt work on an oil rig or date a waitress with country western aspirations for the progressive optics, or even to alienate his family. His drive for adventure, to negate all semblance of former identity, comes from a sincere, obscure place buried deep in his heart. By 1970, this archetype ‚Äî the privileged societal drop-out who leaves home to, per Simon and Garfunkel, ‚Äúlook for America‚Äù ‚Äî had amassed some clich√©s in a post-Summer of Love culture. In the hands of most actors, Bobby Dupea would resemble a collection of affectations instead of a whole human being. But Jack Nicholson is not ‚Äúmost actors,‚Äù and thus he imbues the protagonist of Bon Rafelson‚Äôs ‚ÄúFive Easy Pieces‚Äù with the disordered interiority of a character from literature. He conveys his confused anger and deep-seated sorrow with casual grace, whether he‚Äôs trying to contain his uncouth, terminally sweet girlfriend Rayette (a remarkable Karen Black), or manage his barely-concealed contempt around his blue-blooded family, whom he reluctantly agrees to visit in the Pacific Northwest after hearing about his patriarch‚Äôs poor health. It‚Äôs only the presence of the earnest, grounded Catherine (Susan Anspach), a piano student studying at his family home who‚Äôs attracted to Bobby but can‚Äôt stomach his apathy, that challenges his hard exterior. The film is defined by an existential melancholy, accented by L√°szl√≥ Kov√°cs‚Äôs painterly photography and conveyed through Nicholson‚Äôs performance. In its most famous scene, Bobby patiently confronts a stubborn diner waitress whose strict adherence to the establishment‚Äôs ‚Äúno substitutions‚Äù policy has made it impossible for him to order a side of toast. (‚ÄúYou want to hold the chicken salad?‚Äù the waitress sneers. ‚ÄúI want you to hold it between your knees,‚Äù Bobby famously responds.) Though funny and righteous, the scene‚Äôs anti-establishment fervor is tinged with despair. However clever he may be, Bobby just can‚Äôt adapt to the customs of a diner, let alone his family or America. He doesn‚Äôt get his toast, he doesn‚Äôt land the girl he wants or already has, and he doesn‚Äôt find purpose. But as the ending indicates, nothing will stop him from trying. ‚ÄîVM Almost certainly the greatest student film ever made, ‚ÄúEraserhead‚Äù was made by a young David Lynch with a budget of $100,000, a series of soundstages and sets owned by the American Film Institute, and a wife and child he was caring for at home. From those humble beginnings, Lynch created something immortal ‚Äî a stark and enigmatic hallucination that feels untethered to any specific time or place, but continues to endure as a result of its hyper-potent elusiveness. Inspired by his experiences of fatherhood, and his time living with his young family in the Fairmont neighborhood of Philadelphia, Lynch transports ‚ÄúEraserhead‚Äù viewers to an industrial landscape that feels devoid of light and hope, where the hapless hero (Jack Nance, with an iconic shock of frazzled hair) struggles to care for the strange monster his girlfriend gave birth to. With evocative black-and-white photography Frederick Elmes and Herbert Cardwell, along with unnerving sound design from Lynch himself that disorients at every turn, ‚ÄúEraserhead‚Äù is a work of remarkable craft far beyond its modest origins ‚Äî and a heartbreaking portrait of parental anxiety that will find purchase with a new generation of viewers for as long as movies can still find their cults. ‚ÄîWC Barbara Kopple‚Äôs landmark documentary opens with shots of Kentucky coal miners lying flat on a conveyer belt as they slide down the depths of the Brookside Mine, literalizing the pernicious capitalistic notion of human beings as tools. She spends the remainder of the film illustrating the dignity and resolve of those same miners as they strike against the Eastover Coal Company for refusing to honor their union contract with the United Mine Workers of America (UMWA). Kopple‚Äôs righteous on-the-ground filmmaking goes within people‚Äôs homes and behind picket lines to capture the miners‚Äô effectively confrontational tactics and the unsustainable conditions that made the strike inevitable, including Eastover‚Äôs indifference to basic safety standards, which lead to prevalent cases of black lung amongst the laborers, and the Duke Power Company‚Äôs record profit increases while worker wages stagnate compared to the cost of living. As ‚ÄúHarlan County, USA‚Äù makes clear, Brookside miners were never going to quietly die in squalor without a fight. Kopple leverages the best of v√©rit√© techniques to immerse audiences into Harlan County‚Äôs social and economic milieu while refusing to strictly adhere to direct cinema orthodoxy. She seamlessly incorporates archival footage, fly-on-the-wall observational footage of union meetings, direct interviews with miners and their wives, and spare use of expositional intertitles to situate viewers in the present-tense moment. Though her primary motivation was to document the struggle, Kopple rarely sacrifices aesthetics in pursuit of that goal. Close-ups of hardened miner faces often speak louder than their words. Transitional montages of poverty-line life soundtracked by folk music illuminate the necessity of labor conflicts in America. A magnificent single take depicts the strikers, who have blocked off a public road leading to the mines, demand the local sheriff deliver an arrest warrant to head gun thug Basil Collins, who sits in a line of cars waiting to threaten the picketers. ‚ÄúHarlan County, USA‚Äù typifies the emotional power of worker solidarity exhibited in union meetings and funerals, in demonstrations outside the Duke Power‚Äôs North Carolina and on Wall Street. Yet, Kopple is careful not to tip into convenient utopian thinking. As much as the film was created in part to generate a manual for labor organizers, she depicts how hard-fought gains can be just as easily nullified by a divided workforce or ineffectual union leadership. Rhyming with the opening scenes, ‚ÄúHarlan County, USA‚Äù closing sequence features miners leaving Brookside mine after another day of drudgery. Kopple‚Äôs point is potently unsubtle: as long as people need to work to live, and as long management believes in profits over people, the fight will continue. ‚ÄîVM Unsparing and uncompromising, Martha Coolidge‚Äôs debut feature documents its own creation while also re-staging the director‚Äôs adolescent rape. Coolidge‚Äôs metafictional approach provides the director and her actors ‚Äî Michele Manenti, who plays Coolidge as a teenager and is herself a sexual assault victim, and Jim Carrington, who plays Coolidge‚Äôs attacker ‚Äî the venue to process trauma without mitigating its horrors. The narrative scenes of a young Martha going on a date from hell and then having to face the judgment of her boarding school dorm-mates never once play like a chintzy after-school special, even as the audience remains constantly aware of their artificial nature. Meanwhile, the fourth-wall-breaking sequences, when Coolidge discusses rape culture and gendered approaches to sexuality with her actors, both of whom bravely commit to the project while also being rattled by the material, startle in their emotional honesty and notable lack of judgment. In the interim 50 years, Americans have become slightly ‚Äî slightly ‚Äî more conscious of the prevalence of sexual assault, the importance of consent, and the insidiousness of victim blaming. Yet, ‚ÄúNot a Pretty Picture‚Äù never once feels dated in its insights or approach. On the contrary, it feels sadly contemporary. By embracing the constructed unreality of her real-life memory while simultaneously witnessing actors dedicate themselves to its authenticity, Coolidge generates a quietly cathartic experience. ‚ÄúNot a Pretty Picture‚Äù never functions like an educational text (though Carrington admits the film could serve that purpose), and Coolidge doesn‚Äôt pretend to be in the business of imparting lessons on her actors or her audience. Still, it‚Äôs clear that everyone involved comes away affected by the project. Coolidge situates her cast and crew and the audience inside and outside her life-altering experience in order for them to viscerally feel her pain while also intellectually consider it. One of the great debut features of the decade, ‚ÄúNot a Pretty Picture‚Äù acutely understands that cinema offers an illusory space, one whose inherently manufactured nature allows memories to be projected and ensnared where they can be experienced without being relived. ‚ÄîVM At a retrospective screening last December, Elaine May clarified that while her downbeat buddy comedy ‚ÄúMikey and Nicky‚Äù does have laughs, they‚Äôre ‚Äújust not the cheery kind.‚Äù Inspired by May‚Äôs observations of low-level gangsters in Chicago, the film explores male friendship at its most abject, as two lifelong pals ‚Äî one a maudlin drunk played by John Cassavetes, the other a practical family man embodied by Peter Falk ‚Äî embark upon an ostensibly freewheeling nighttime journey towards a sobering and inevitable dawn. Misunderstood, like much of May‚Äôs work, upon its initial release, ‚ÄúMikey and Nicky‚Äù has seen found its rightful purchase as a classic thanks to May‚Äôs incisive screenwriting and the believably desperate performances of her stars. ‚ÄîKR Among everything else you could say about George Lucas‚Äôs cinematic cosmic cocktail: Is this simply the most talked about movie of all time? If so, that makes finding something new to offer on the subject a major challenge. And yet, the richness of this work is such that there always seems to be another angle to explore. Like how a camera had never tilted and panned through a starfield before ‚ÄúStar Wars.‚Äù Or how the ‚ÄúMos Eisley Cantina‚Äù theme is basically just Dixieland jazz with a little bit of the Charleston added in for good measure.
