Or the extraordinary narrative choice to just plunge viewers into the middle of the action and leave it to viewers to get their own bearings ‚Äî there‚Äôs never an explanation of what a Jawa is or why they‚Äôve suddenly kidnapped our droid heroes, they just are. You figure it out. That‚Äôs Lucas‚Äôs soft-spoken invitation to us to explore this galaxy on our own and find our own way around ‚Äî and millions upon millions formed their own personal connection with ‚ÄúStar Wars‚Äù as a result. When you find your own way to something, it‚Äôs always a more powerful bond than when it‚Äôs imposed on you. Critics always like to point out the way that ‚ÄúStar Wars‚Äù stands on the shoulders of Old Hollywood adventure serials like ‚ÄúFlash Gordon,‚Äù but as much as Lucas excavated the past, he reinterpreted it too, through his generational post-Vietnam lens. Tunisia doesn‚Äôt just replace, say, Monument Valley for a desert landscape, Lucas also has it that the Empire massacres a group of indigenous people early in the film and clumsily tries to hide their murders by pinning it on another indigenous group. Then has the Empire destroy an entire planet, basically just because it can. For as much as it‚Äôs a standalone film, ‚ÄúStar Wars‚Äù is also a rewarding companion piece to ‚ÄúAmerican Graffiti.‚Äù That film is all about a teenager questioning whether he really wants to leave home, about ‚Äúrefusing the call‚Äù in Joseph Campbell terms. ‚ÄúStar Wars‚Äù is all about what happens after, when you‚Äôve actually left. How you have to find out who you are and what you‚Äôre made of, and put together a new family you find along the way. We may not have to take on a Death Star first thing, but the leap that we all have to take in growing up has rarely found a more universal expression than it does in ‚ÄúStar Wars.‚Äù ‚ÄîCB Humble Italian peasants living at the end of the 19th century serve as the collective protagonist of Ermanno Olmi‚Äôs gorgeously orchestrated, Palme d‚ÄôOr-winning pastoral saga. Men, women, and children toll away day in and day out on fields that don‚Äôt belong to them ‚Äî all to enrich the wealthy landowner while they struggle to survive on what little they are allowed to keep. Under these precarious circumstances, where every pair of hands is put to use doing manual labor, sending a child to school is a luxury few can afford. One couple decides to spring for it anyway, as the local priest has encourage them to nourish their boy‚Äôs God-given intelligence in the hopes that their sacrifice may pay off down the road. But that‚Äôs only one story in this boisterous farmhouse of tales. We also a widow trying to support her six children by washing other people‚Äôs clothes, and several young people who seek love in a reality where the death of a farm animal ‚Äî or even something as small as a broken shoe ‚Äî can test a family‚Äôs resilience. And as calamity befalls them, their only solace is the belief that somehow the grace of God will pull them from their desperation. The brilliance of Olmi‚Äôs ensemble piece lies in how organically, and unhurriedly, it weaves in and out of each family‚Äôs vicissitudes, while also offering glimpses into the unrest that‚Äôs brewing beyond the confines of this community. ‚ÄîCA From the poorly designed stunts that brutalized Ellen Burstyn and 14-year-old Linda Blair, to filmmaker William Friedkin‚Äôs infamous use of the so-called ‚Äúpractical scare‚Äù on set (he reportedly fired real guns at will to keep his actors alert), ‚ÄúThe Exorcist‚Äù is a cinematic masterpiece ‚Äî and horrifying in more ways than one. I haven‚Äôt even gotten into that mysterious studio fire, yet! The unnerving and electric possession of Regan MacNeil was adapted by screenwriter William Peter Blatty from his 1971 novel. The story, particularly its Georgetown setting, was inspired by a real case of attempted exorcism documented by the Catholic Church in 1948, but Blatty and Friedkin‚Äôs influence hung over the 1970s in the shadows of ‚ÄúThe Exorcist‚Äù and its varied successors. Between works like Richard Donner‚Äôs monumental ‚ÄúThe Omen‚Äù (1976), and John Boorman‚Äôs divisive, locus-infested ‚ÄúExorcist II: The Heretic‚Äù (1977), not every cinematic follow-up to ‚ÄúThe Exorcist‚Äù feels worthy of its association with the Oscar winner for Best Adapted Screenplay. (It also took home Best Sound.) But you could argue the same thing about the countless generically named ‚ÄúCreepy Girl‚Äù props you‚Äôll find resembling Blair in haunted decoration stands every Halloween‚Ä¶ and who doesn‚Äôt love those? Worth making the predictable word choice to call it ‚Äúhead-spinning‚Äù at least once, ‚ÄúThe Exorcist‚Äù begins slow ‚Äî stewing in the sands of an archaeological dig that unleashes a terror from the pitch-black depths of hell onto a little girl and her woefully screwed mom in D.C. If you don‚Äôt know the face of Pazuzu yet, you will have that unholy magic burned into your brain after just one viewing. Father Damien Karras (Jason Miller) tries his best, but decades later, the late actor‚Äôs son, who is now a genre filmmaker himself, is still grappling with what happened to the unlucky man on those godforsaken stairs. ‚ÄîAF The opening shot of blaxploitation was significantly more radical than what came after. Multi-hyphenate creator Melvin Van Peebles‚Äô goal with this 1971 firebomb ‚Äî which came in the wake of his first and only Hollywood production, ‚ÄúThe Watermelon Man‚Äù ‚Äî was nothing less than a complete annihilation of conventional cinematic form, as he defied every rule of Hollywood production and editing to create ‚Äúthe first Black Power film‚Äù (even going so far as to arm his crew). Bolstered by the support of the Black Panther Party and the tagline, ‚ÄúRated X by an All-White Jury,‚Äù Van Peebles‚Äô missive became a massive box office hit despite ‚Äî or perhaps because of ‚Äî its unblinking approach to sex and brutality. Fifty years on, ‚ÄúSweet Sweetback‚Äôs Badasssss Song‚Äù is still incendiary, challenging, and one of a kind. ‚ÄîKR An unsparingly nativist satire of colonial arrogance, Nelson Pereira dos Santos‚Äô cinema novo masterpiece remains one of film history‚Äôs most cutting rebukes against the white savior narrative that it has done so much to propagate over the last 125 years. Set in 16th century Brazil, the deliciously titled ‚ÄúHow Tasty Was My Little Frenchman‚Äù stars Ardu√≠no Colassanti as an unnamed settler who‚Äôs captured by the indigenous Tupinamb√°s ‚Äî who believe him to be Portuguese ‚Äî and told that he will be ritualistically eaten in eight months. It‚Äôs not a promising situation for our protagonist, but after being assigned a young wife (Ana Maria Magalh√£es as Seboipepe) and given free run of her village, our blond ‚Äúhero‚Äù begins to grow comfortable in his new surroundings. He even starts to adopt the local customs and dress (or lack thereof), confident that his captors will come to recognize the savagery of their own customs in the face of his evolved Christian grace. He even appears to fall in love with Seboipepe, and assumes the feeling is mutual. Spoiler alert: There‚Äôs a reason why this movie isn‚Äôt called ‚ÄúI Didn‚Äôt Eat My Husband.‚Äù It turns out that Seboipepe is mostly concerned with claiming the best piece of white meat. From its title on down, ‚ÄúHow Tasty Was My Little Frenchman‚Äù is inflexibly ‚Äî gleefully ‚Äî rooted in the perspective of the Tupinamb√°s, whose understanding of the world has been untainted by the hegemony of the European invaders. That ahistorical point-of-view will ultimately lead to their extermination, but not before Pereira dos Santos is able to reverse the time-honored prejudices of Western filmmaking and create a story that identifies with the conquered at all costs. In doing so, he offers a bitingly sardonic reminder that history is easier to swallow than it is to digest. ‚ÄîDE A product of the Direct Cinema movement of observational documentary filmmaking that gave birth to masterpieces like ‚ÄúGrey Gardens‚Äù and ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Look Back,‚Äù ‚ÄúGimme Shelter‚Äù was born when directors Albert and David Maysles and Charlotte Zwerin were allowed to tag along on the final three weeks of the Rolling Stones‚Äô legendary 1969 tour. What could have been a straightforward rock doc ‚Äî featuring some impressive behind-the-scenes footage and performances from the legendary band ‚Äî instead became a chronicle of something far greater when the filmmakers captured the infamous Altamont Free Concert that capped the group‚Äôs American leg, complete with footage of the killing of concertgoer Meredith Hunter. Shot with a hazy lens that appropriately feels like an acid trip, ‚ÄúGimme Shelter‚Äù documents all the managerial and organizational failure that allowed the concert to descend into chaos, and the discordant, nightmarish events of the night itself. One of the rawest and most unvarnished non-fiction films of its time period, ‚ÄúGimme Shelter‚Äù is more than a concert doc, its a portrait of a changing era, as the dreams of the ‚Äò60s made way for the cynicism of the ‚Äò70s. ‚ÄîWC Few actors embody everything great about ‚Äò70s cinema better than Gene Hackman. A late bloomer who seemingly stumbled backwards into an acting career, his unvarnished everyman characters were highlights of many of the decade‚Äôs best films. And his talents were never put to better use than as Harry R. Caul (a homophonically droll name for a wiretapper), a surveillance expert who falls down a rabbit hole of paranoia after hearing what he believes to be dangerous information that could affect a couple he was hired to spy on. The performance takes a quintessential Hollywood archetype ‚Äî the washed up man who has long sworn off morality after being haunted by past mistakes ‚Äî and updates it for a world in which nobody felt like they could trust a word that anyone else was saying. Francis Ford Coppola, in the midst of his all-time great filmmaking run, is at the height of his technical powers, using intricately composed shots of San Francisco and brilliant sound design to illustrate Caul‚Äôs mastery of surveillance and his earned distrust in the people who employ him. But the stylization is all grounded in the sad portrait of the character‚Äôs life that Coppola and Hackman paint for us. I have personally never attended a surveillance equipment convention, but it‚Äôs not hard to imagine how quickly your trust would erode if you spent all of your days hanging out with private sector spies eager to brag about the latest answering machine they broke into. Amid a sea of self-described paranoid thrillers from a very paranoid decade, ‚ÄúThe Conversation‚Äù stands out among the finest because it managed to meet a national moment without ever having to diverge from its protagonist‚Äôs natural truths. ‚ÄîCZ In the films of Jacques Rivette, Paris is less a city than a giant stage or playground upon which characters project imagined dramas, but none of his work takes that idea to a more fantastical extreme than ‚ÄúDuelle.‚Äù Here, Juliet Berto and Bulle Ogier‚Äôs cryptic femmes fatales are not merely young bohemians roaming around town making up conspiracies and mysteries to add spice to their lives but goddesses in mortal form engaged in a contest of wills that predates human life. As the women gradually orient themselves toward their latest cosmic confrontation, they occupy the rest of their time tempting mortals into their thrall with behaviors heavily indebted to classic noir. In the process, Rivette crafts an impressionistic tribute to everything from Marlene Dietrich‚Äôs collaborations with von Sternberg, Weimar-era expressionistic thrillers, even the lucid-dreaming poetic mythology of Jean Cocteau. Eschewing mere homage for a sublimation of past forms into something new, ‚ÄúDuelle‚Äù reconfigures the cinephilia of the Cahiers critic-filmmakers into a vision of cinema as timeless as the oldest myths of the ancient world. ‚ÄîJC Clint Eastwood was already the star and director of numerous westerns by the time he made ‚ÄúThe Outlaw Josey Wales,‚Äù but it was here he fully emerged from the shadows of early collaborators Sergio Leone and Don Siegel to establish himself as the true heir to John Ford‚Äôs vision of the West. Physically and psychologically scarred by the Civil War, Eastwood‚Äôs Josey is a vision of rage so uncontrollable that the massacre of surrendering comrades by Union troops seems more a convenient excuse for inevitable bloodshed than justifiable cause. As in ‚ÄúThe Searchers,‚Äù the film gradually pulls its protagonist back from the edge of damnation, but where Ford‚Äôs movie offers moral clarity at the last possible second, Eastwood‚Äôs confronts its hero‚Äôs anger throughout the story. As Josey assembles a makeshift caravan of Native Americans, harassed homesteaders, and other unfortunate souls, Eastwood draws constant but understated attention to the contrast between the Confederate‚Äôs aggrievement and the larger framework of racial, gender, and class violence in America. Slowly but surely, this wrathful Lost Cause thriller morphs into an unsentimental but nonetheless hopeful vision of community solidarity as the only true defense against the predations of individuals and systems. ‚ÄîJC Winner of the Palme d‚ÄôOr at Cannes in 1975, and still the only African film to have ever been awarded that prize, ‚ÄúChronicles of the Years of Fire‚Äù is both a political epic and a personal account of Algeria‚Äôs struggle for independence. Director Mohammed Lakhdar-Hamina stages the story with large-scale set pieces, poetic monologues, and sweeping cinematography. Crucially, however, he avoids triumphalism at every turn. Instead, his film traces how colonial violence reshaped everyday life and made revolt inevitable. It‚Äôs long, demanding, and often theatrical, but always urgent. Few African films have matched its scale, and even fewer have carried this kind of historical weight on the world stage. ‚ÄîTO Shudder‚Äôs ‚ÄúDario Argento Panico‚Äù is an essential documentary primer for any cinephile just getting into the complex, supersaturated legacy of Italy‚Äôs most notorious genre filmmaker. Understanding the dark psychology of a man who conjured up unfathomable suspense and horror ‚Äî then repeatedly cast his real wife and kids as exquisite centerpieces in those artful nightmares ‚Äî is, how do you say, ‚Äútutta una cosa.‚Äù That‚Äôs Italian for ‚Äúa whole thing,‚Äù and basically the entire point for dedicated fans of the director. Effectively standing in for a decade of brilliant giallo on this list, ‚ÄúSuspiria‚Äù is more than up to the task. The eerie magic Argento first conjured up in 1977 is best remembered for its illustrious use of color, even with ‚ÄúDeep Red‚Äù right there in the director‚Äôs filmography. The crimson splatters and jewel-colored glass that adorn the German ballet school where ‚ÄúSuspiria‚Äù takes place make it a crowning achievement in the pantheon of visual horror. That masterful dreamscape is reflected in the eyes of a young American dancer, Suzy Bannion (Jessica Harper), whose serpentine descent into supernatural madness plays out like a lethal recital on psychedelics. Loosely translated, ‚ÄúSuspiria‚Äù means ‚Äúbreathing‚Äù or ‚Äúto take a deep breath.‚Äù That quietly sensual undercurrent might explain why ‚ÄúChallengers‚Äù director Luca Guadagnino and ‚Äú50 Shades‚Äù muse Dakota Johnson teamed up to revive Argento‚Äôs classic as a high-concept art film with a well-disguised Tilda Swinton in the critically-acclaimed remake from 2018. The original can‚Äôt evoke quite the same visceral response as that film‚Äôs updated effects, but anyone whose seen the atrium-hanging sequence should be able to convince you to watch both versions. Trite but true, there‚Äôs more than one way for a witch to step on your neck. ‚ÄîAF One of the final films by the great Luis Bu√±uel, ‚ÄúThe Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoise‚Äù moves from dinner party to dinner party in a disorienting haze, each moment bleeding into the next. True to its title, the cast of characters we follow are a group of six well-off French men and women, each containing a sense of smug satisfaction and an underlying restlessness in their comfortable, mannered lives. Their attempts to dine together are thwarted by a series of vignettes both ‚Äúreal‚Äù and dreamed, from terrorist attacks to ghostly encounters to the discovery that their lives are actually a stage play. Bu√±uel‚Äôs comedy is dry as a bone, with each absurdity readily accepted by the passive ensemble. The film pokes and prods them mercilessly, with each mishap peeling away at the fundamental spiritual rot within them. It‚Äôs that unflinching meanness towards its own characters that makes ‚ÄúThe Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoise‚Äù one of the great satires in all of film history. ‚ÄîWC So much of Ingmar Bergman‚Äôs work was defined by the women who brought his intimate, existential dramas to life, and with whom he frequently had tempestuous romances off-screen. Kicking off an impressive late-period run from the Swedish auteur before his retirement in 1982, ‚ÄúCries and Whispers,‚Äù gives one of his first muses ‚Äî Harriet Andersson ‚Äî a harrowing showcase that doubles as a reflection on how much time has passed since she was the ingenue launched to stardom by Bergman‚Äôs ‚ÄúSummer With Monika.‚Äù In this austere psychological tragedy, Andersson plays a noblewoman tucked away in a country manor dying slowly from disease, with two sisters (Liv Ullmann and Ingrid Thulin) who are distant to both her and each other. As flashbacks reveal the cruelties that curdled this family, Bergman and cinematographer Sven Nykvist bathe the film in a stark red glow, bringing fire to an icy, despairing work. And Andersson is devastating as the frail woman at the center, giving her last leading performance for the director whom her career was forever intertwined. ‚ÄîWC Glowing and electric, George A. Romero‚Äôs masterful ‚ÄúNight of the Living Dead‚Äù (1968) is iconic for a reason. But the sequel that followed his feature debut a decade later, ‚ÄúDawn of the Dead‚Äù (1978), lies at the heart of a truly beloved filmography. Despite studio interference and a lack of financial stability throughout his otherwise successful artistic life, Romero is remembered as the sensitive American filmmaker whose steadfast commitment to the underdog gave the cinematic undead their reputation for social consciousness. At their most memorable, scary movies have long reflected how we can do better as people ‚Äî alone or en masse. Created after several years of its director exploring other less terrifying realms, Romero‚Äôs genre homecoming endures as a remarkable collaboration between him, co-producer Dario Argento, the musical group known as the Band Goblin (credited in the film as The Goblins), and special effects wizard Tom Savini. The strongest and most ghoulish worship comes from community, and the action, comedy, and horror film worlds socialize as much as the artists here. Set inside a shopping mall, ‚ÄúDawn of the Dead‚Äù sees combat collide with corpses as the zombie apocalypse from the first movie blooms into a bigger production for Romero. This nightmare is more philosophically complex, too. (Not like ‚ÄúDay of the Dead‚Äù levels of enlightenment, but you know, within reason.) Romero‚Äôs script masterfully disassembles the concept of a literal safe house under capitalism to explore the complacency it breeds, and to suggest that even the bravest leaders among us won‚Äôt know to burn it all down until it‚Äôs too late. ‚ÄîAF Med Hondo‚Äôs 1979 epic is so compelling that merely describing it is sufficient justification for its inclusion on this list. Filmed aboard a reconstructed slave ship inside an abandoned French factory, with a budget totalling $1.35 million (making it the most expensive African film ever at the time), ‚ÄúWest Indies‚Äù is a musical satire/non-linear historiography of French colonialism. It is a whirlwind of post-Fanon interpolations with an unsparing, furious clarity of purpose. Hondo paints the history of the Caribbean under French rule as one where revolution is co-opted by capitalism, where artistic expression is disallowed without sufficient cultural assimilation, and where violence and displacement persist under the guise of progress. All of this might have amounted to little more than a politically astute curio were it not for Hondo‚Äôs total command of Western spectacle. ‚ÄúWest Indies‚Äù has some of the greatest musical numbers ever filmed, with a dizzying sense of scale, intricacy, and imagination. Hondo plainly outdoes many of the pop artists he satirizes. The result is a blisteringly intelligent referendum on the rotten core of Euro-American cinema, and an equally potent tribute to the resilient fullness of African cultures. ‚ÄîSB The money alone is notable: Made for less than $9 million, ‚ÄúJaws‚Äù went on to make over $470 million in global returns, including a $260 million domestic take that earned it the top spot at the box office in 1975. The film toppled other high-powered hits like ‚ÄúOne Flew Over the Cuckoo‚Äôs Nest‚Äù and ‚ÄúDog Day Afternoon,‚Äù all huge moneymakers that were decidedly non-blockbuster in nature. And ‚ÄúJaws‚Äù was the first feature film to break $235 million in domestic returns. Steven Spielberg‚Äôs big hit ‚Äî his first, and obviously not his last ‚Äî paved the way for the massive tentpole features that now dominate the summer season, huge earners that capture both the zeitgeist and hefty audiences. The secret? It‚Äôs one that filmmakers of any generation can stand to learn, remember, and take to heart: the film is good. So many blockbusters not only eschew overall quality in service to whiz-bang entertainment and speedy fun, but they do it with truly disposal amusements. Nothing about ‚ÄúJaws‚Äù is throwaway. Meticulously built from stem to stern, ‚ÄúJaws‚Äù takes pains to steep us in the world of small-town Amity (it means friendship!) long before a seriously large and biblically pissed off shark makes mincemeat of many of its citizens and everyone‚Äôs nerves. Neatly divided into two distinct sections ‚Äì a landlubbing first half that tracks a small town on the edge, none of it helped by a mayor who doesn‚Äôt really see a need to mess with holiday fun, no matter how many people die, followed by an alternately claustrophobic and just kinda fun death sail on the high seas ‚Äî ‚ÄúJaws‚Äù builds both its tension and character evolution with steady hands. While we may briefly wonder who is going to beat this thing ‚Äì Ocean-adverse chief of police Martin Brody (Roy Scheider)? Grizzled fisherman and battered war hero Quint (Robert Shaw)? Know-it-all wino marine biologist Matt Hooper (Richard Dreyfuss)? ‚Äì the real question is, who is going to survive and what the hell does that even look like? Luckily for us, ‚ÄúJaws‚Äù itself endures. ‚ÄîKE Jacques Rivette‚Äôs prankish, exuberant, and restlessly energetic ‚ÄúC√©line and Julie Go Boating‚Äù boasts one of the all-time great cinematic friendships. It‚Äôs also a total explosion of the rules of cinematic storytelling, and one of the most innovative features of the 1970s ‚Äî no small feat. Dominique Labourier plays Julie, a reverie-prone librarian who meets C√©line (Juliet Berto) in a sequence straight out of Lewis Carroll, as C√©line keeps dropping objects that Julie can‚Äôt chase her down fast enough to return. That sets the stage for an enchanting, but never precious or twee, tale of doubles‚Ä¶ in addition to a love triangle, a mysterious house, and a subplot about a psychedelic candy that allows the two women ‚Äî who become fast friends and roommates after that chance meeting ‚Äî to seemingly bend the rules of time altogether. Here‚Äôs where Rivette tosses yet another genre, the murder mystery melodrama, into ‚ÄúC√©line and Julie‚Äù in ways that gleefully reinvent the very references he‚Äôs trying to make and then subvert. ‚ÄúC√©line and Julie Go Boating‚Äù feels in many ways like the original hangout movie of the 1970s, bouncing along episodically, more jaunty picaresque than manic pixie dream girl omnibus. Despite running nearly three-and-a-half hours, this allusion-heavy (and illusion-heavy) movie is made totally accessible by Rivette‚Äôs disorienting and tradition-disrupting style. More than that, it feels like a fresh discovery each time you rewatch it. ‚ÄîRL ‚ÄúEverything begins and ends at the exactly right time and place,‚Äù says an Australian schoolgirl with dead eyes and a breathy, bated voice at a pivotal moment in Peter Weir‚Äôs lastingly elusive ‚ÄúPicnic at Hanging Rock.‚Äù Ushering in a New Wave of Australian 1970s cinema that put the country‚Äôs film scene on the global map, Weir‚Äôs masterpiece remains equally influential for contemporary filmmakers such as Sofia Coppola, who picked up Weir‚Äôs mantle as the cinema‚Äôs reigning master of dazed blonde women strung out on fainting couches. Like patterns in the clouds, you can read almost anything into the bottomless pit of mystery that becomes the center of this unforgettably strange portrait of sexual repression, written by screenwriter Cliff Green. It‚Äôs Valentine‚Äôs Day, 1900, at the fictional all-girls boarding school called Appleyard College, where a group of students head out toward a geological formation, Hanging Rock, in Victoria. Three vanish without a trace, seemingly into a crevice in the formation. The sighting of a strange red cloud that coincided with the three young women‚Äôs seeming evaporation into nowhere, as told by Edith (Christine Schuler), could be read as a limpid, subtle-as-a-chainsaw metaphor for looming femininity and the disappearances themselves as the loss of innocence into adulthood. More memorable than its symbolism, however, is the seductive, ethereal, and dread-spiked atmosphere ‚ÄúPicnic at Hanging Rock‚Äù conjures, leaving you in as dazed a spell as the protagonists whose dilemma remains stubbornly unsolved. That‚Äôs where Weir‚Äôs chillingly directed film gets its extraordinary power. ‚ÄîRL Banned after the 1979 Iranian Revolution and thought lost for decades, Mohammad Reza Aslani‚Äôs miraculous ‚ÄúChess of the Wind‚Äù wasn‚Äôt widely seen until its 2020 restoration, when it arrived with the feeling of a priceless discovery. Set almost entirely inside a decaying aristocratic mansion in early 20th century Tehran, the film is a tightly controlled chamber drama about inheritance and control. A paralyzed woman battles her stepfamily for power, while servants lurk and loyalties shift in silence. The stillness is deceptive; every movement, glance, and sound is loaded with meaning. Its surface recalls the visual grammar of 1970s festival auteurs, but Aslani builds a world anchored in the historical textures of Iranian society, shaped by class conflict, gendered power, and a quiet subversion of patriarchy. Its formal control and long absence make it one of the most arresting rediscoveries in recent world cinema history. ‚ÄîTO The fate of the midnight movie is still pretty much at the mercy of kids who can‚Äôt decide if they should cancel each other for liking ‚ÄúThe Rocky Horror Picture Show.‚Äù But Brian de Palma‚Äôs ‚ÄúPhantom of the Paradise‚Äù reigns supreme as the definitive best piece of flashy genre cinema from the 1970s ‚Äî a glorious ode to a rocker punished for his passion that was itself tortured on its rocky road to theaters. Thanks to a nonsensical legal challenge from Led Zeppelin, moviegoers have to be pretty lucky to catch De Palma‚Äôs extraordinary 1974 glam opera as it was meant to be seen. Censorship plagues all publicly available versions of the film, and a particularly egregious restoration from a physical media release a few years ago left many fans disturbed by the intricate production details lost to its poorly updated color. Still, whichever version you watch, the tragic tale of musical genius Winslow Leach (William Finley) shines through as a timeless testament to the power of talented freaks with a song to sing. Paul Williams scored ‚ÄúPhantom of the Paradise,‚Äù which also casts the Grammy-winning composer as the villainous namesake executive for Swan Records. Swan destroys what could be a quick rise to fame for Winslow and his band, The Juicy Fruits, when he steals the basis for their first hit song. Enter Beef (Gerrit Graham), a competitive diva whose effort to help Swan screw over Winslow ends explosively. The glittery terror that surrounds that reveal commingles bejeweled platforms and fishnets (with some of the more disturbing elements of the Gypsy Rose Blanchard story?) in a singular ‚ÄúPhantom of the Opera‚Äù homage. It also sees ‚ÄúSuspiria‚Äù final girl Jessica Harper centerstage as its fresh-faced Angel of Music in a performance that could almost make you forget the movies‚Äô later attempts at creating their own Christine. ‚ÄîAF Dripping with style and sick with unease in its portrait of an emotionally detached man (Jean Louis-Trintignant) hired to assassinate his ex-fascist former professor, Bernardo Bertolucci‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Conformist‚Äù illuminates its protagonist‚Äôs psyche with a scintillating dance of light and shadow ‚Äî an approach that would have an enormous influence on Francis Ford Coppola as he ramped up to make ‚ÄúThe Godfather.‚Äù Shooting in Rome and Paris as well as Cinecitt√† Studios in Italy, production designer Ferdinando Scarfiotti and cinematographer Vittorio Storaro (unjustly robbed of an Oscar nomination for his hugely influential work here) summoned the vibes of 1930s Fascist Italy with extraordinary detail, emboldened by Bertolucci‚Äôs baroque style. At the center of this cold ‚Äî but never bloodless ‚Äî movie is the relationship between Marcello (Trintignant) and Anna (Dominique Sanda), the professor‚Äôs wife whom he falls in love with fatal consequences. Those consequences are realized in a disturbing and suspenseful sequence that elegantly summarizes the movie‚Äôs themes of cowardice, repression, betrayal, offering an ultimate reminder of Marcello‚Äôs own fecklessness. Antiheroes became a dominant trademark of 1970s cinema both abroad and in the United States; look toward the moral complexities of Marcello for an early figurehead of that trope, all wrapped up in a doom-laden but ecstatically glorious movie. ‚ÄîRL A three-part nonfiction epic, Patricio Guzman‚Äôs black-and-white masterpiece is unrivaled as the premier filmic document preserving the memory of Chile before, during, and after one of its most troubled chapters, which has defined its modern history. Starting in the months before military dictator Augusto Pinochet came to power by force, Guzman set his camera against a country in crisis. The first installment, 1975‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Insurrection of the Bourgeoisie,‚Äù hinges on the director‚Äôs interviews with working class people as they take to the streets to demonstrate in defense of Salvador Allende‚Äôs government, and to denounce how the elite has fought to maintain their privileged position at the expense of the masses. On the ground amid the turmoil, ‚ÄúThe Coup d‚Äô√©tat‚Äù goes on to bear witness to violent clashes, hopeful protests, ardent speeches, and ultimately to the U.S.-backed overthrow of Allende on September 11, 1973, which ushered in a dark period for the South American nation. The final part, ‚ÄúPopular Power,‚Äù winds back the clock to serve as something of a prequel, as Guzman explores the proletariat‚Äôs frustrated attempts at reclaiming their power. Although forced into exile for decades, the acclaimed filmmaker has since continued to observe Chile‚Äôs transformation over the years, and to investigate his own complicated relationship with the country of his birth in several subsequent works (including 1997‚Äôs ‚ÄúChile, Obstinate Memory,‚Äù which found Guzman screening his trilogy for Chileans who had never seen it before). But none of those later projects, strong as they are, can hope to match the potency of watching history change from within the eye of the storm. ‚ÄîCA It‚Äôs impossible to study ‚ÄúApocalypse Now‚Äù in a vacuum, as the film‚Äôs legacy will always be defined by the history surrounding it: the famously harrowing shoot that pushed Francis Ford Coppola to his limits and inspired the excellent documentary ‚ÄúHearts of Darkness: A Filmmaker‚Äôs Apocalypse,‚Äù the dramatic Cannes premiere where Coppola‚Äôs massive bet paid off with a Palme d‚ÄôOr win, and the director‚Äôs insistence to continue revising it into the 21st century. But even without succumbing to the crass temptation to use filmmaking as a metaphor for war, time and distance have proved that the chaos underscoring ‚ÄúApocalypse Now‚Äù have only strengthened its legacy. The most appropriately pessimistic film by one of America‚Äôs greatest optimists, it‚Äôs now easy to see ‚ÄúApocalypse Now‚Äù as the end of the New Hollywood era. That has far more to do with correlation than causation, but it‚Äôs also symbolically fitting: After a decade of watching the industry release auteur-driven films about the gaping hole that the Vietnam War left in America society, Coppola tackled the war that lurked over the decade‚Äôs other masterpieces so directly that it‚Äôs hard to shake the feeling that filmmakers moved on because there was nothing left to say. It would be impossible to determine exactly how much of the film‚Äôs chaos was pre-planned, and how much emerged naturally from a shoot so grueling shoot that it seemed as if God was determined to punish the auteur for his ambition. But Coppola‚Äôs vision resonated for a reason, and the pairing of his prescient foresight ‚Äî about how the military would evolve in a direction of specialization that allows for even greater brutality ‚Äî and the lucid observation that war brings out sides of men that they‚Äôre not capable of looking in the mirror proved to be a lethal combo. ‚ÄúApocalypse Now‚Äù is New Hollywood radicalism executed on a scale that few of his peers ever received a chance to try. It‚Äôs a coda to two eras of American history, one artistic and one historical, and remains the definitive portrayal of a war that defined a generation. ‚ÄîCZ This isn‚Äôt to say that Hollis Frampton‚Äôs ‚Äú(nostalgia)‚Äù is necessarily the greatest experimental film of the 1970s (competition for that useless title abounds, even from the other chapters of the artist‚Äôs ‚ÄúHapax Legomena‚Äù film cycle), but rather to argue that it might be the most productive experimental film of the 1970s to put on a commercial-oriented list such as this one. Epitomizing the ‚Äústructural‚Äù cinema movement that Frampton rejected as a coherent framework, ‚Äú(nostalgia‚Äù) is a singularly potent gateway drug to another universe of moviemaking ‚Äî one in which the shape of a film can be the ultimate expression of its content. To watch ‚Äú(nostalgia‚Äù) is to discover, reconnect with, or simply exalt in the idea that there is something inherently profound, and in this case also extremely poignant, to the materials and construction of cinema itself. Here, the materials are simple, their construction is plain, and the deep well of feeling that Frampton conjures between them is raw, lucid, and inviting. Thirty-eight minutes. Thirteen photographs. One electric burner. A formative picture from the early days of the filmmaker‚Äôs career is placed on a hot plate, where it disintegrates in the flames as a plainspoken voice ‚Äî speaking in the first person, but in fact belonging to avant-garde legend Michael Snow ‚Äî discusses the image in the context of Frampton‚Äôs life. The images are evocatively unremarkable, the narration diaristic yet vaguely wounded. Old friends. Half-forgotten places. A pair of toilets sitting next to each other. Before long, the viewer begins to notice a glitch in the matrix: The narration isn‚Äôt describing the picture on screen, it‚Äôs describing the next picture to come. The effect is as temporally destabilizing as being ambushed by the smell of your childhood home: We‚Äôre hearing about a photograph we haven‚Äôt seen yet, and looking at a photograph we‚Äôve already heard described. That basic misalignment is enough to create a strange and movingly porous middle ground in the space between anticipation and memory, as the pain of reflecting upon the past is dimensionalized by the natural human impulse to cast ourselves forwards into the future. Time eventually reduces it all to ash and silence, but not before Frampton is able to glimpse a fleeting truth of some kind in the movie‚Äôs dying seconds ‚Äî a nowness that no other medium can give us. ‚ÄúHere it is. Look at it! Do you see what I see?‚Äù ‚Äú(nostalgia)‚Äù is an invitation to never stop looking. ‚ÄîDE Has any director ever cared more about how a movie ‚Äúfeels‚Äù than Robert Altman with ‚ÄúMcCabe & Mrs. Miller‚Äù? The film evokes wintry rain and snow and the puffs of dry heat from a pot-belly stove so well you almost feel like you can see Altman‚Äôs breath fogging up the camera lens. One of the greatest of all ‚Äúwinter Westerns,‚Äù this parable about commerce ‚Äî and the role that affection and jealousy and violence play in the holding it all together ‚Äî is an inimitable, oil-lamp-lit gaze into the past that also reflects the light of an eternal present at the same time. Warren Beatty wears a bear-skin coat so thick it makes you warm just to look at it. And he in turn warms the hopes of a small Pacific Northwest logging town with his card-playing skills, rictus grin, and declaration that he‚Äôs a ‚Äúbusinessman.‚Äù Partnering with a veteran madam in Julie Christie, they open a brothel for the town, the one hope for salvation from the grim reality of the everyday ‚Äî especially since the long-awaited Presbyterian Church is never quite finished. If transcendence isn‚Äôt possible, being a sinner can be the best way to endure capitalism. It sure encourages everyone to give it a shot. Pitched between a grimed-up materialism and dreamy aspirations ‚Äî epitomized to perfection by the Leonard Cohen songs Altman put on the soundtrack with lyrics like ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just a Joseph looking for a manger‚Äù ‚Äî ‚ÄúMcCabe & Mrs. Miller‚Äù is the greatest kind of period piece: One that isn‚Äôt an escape into the past, but a way to better understand how we arrived at the present. ‚ÄîCB Shot over a series of weekends in South Central Los Angeles, Charles Burnett‚Äôs ‚ÄúKiller of Sheep‚Äù remains one of the most quietly profound films in all of American cinema. With nonprofessional actors and a focus on everyday detail, it follows a slaughterhouse worker weighed down by routine and fatigue. There is no clear plot, just fragments of life, captured with care and restraint ‚Äî every one of its images feels etched in stone but fully alive at the same time. Burnett, a key figure in the L.A. Rebellion, made a film about Black working-class life without any trace of sentiment or spectacle. Its 2007 restoration brought overdue attention, but the film has always carried the same lucid clarity and profound emotional weight. ‚ÄîTO Screenwriter Paul Schrader‚Äôs compulsion towards male isolation, modern disaffect, and the pursuit of transcendence that promises to alleviate them both has never been more potent than it remains in his original masterpiece. Each of the film‚Äôs unimaginably bold swings lands cleanly because the script does all of the little things right. As so many have pointed out, the appalling choice to make Jodie Foster‚Äôs Iris Steensma a literal child prostitute at just 12-years-old was the only way to create a moral travesty so utterly black-and-white that it could push a morally ambivalent man to forfeit his life for a cause. That transition from fringe observer to self-defined martyr unfolds with perfect cyclicality, affording Travis Bickle a Hero‚Äôs Journey within his own head without giving us any reason to believe that we‚Äôre leaving him any better off. ‚ÄúTaxi Driver‚Äù is in many ways the quintessential New Hollywood film, and so much ink has been spilled about what that means ‚Äî from its unapologetic portrayal of post-Vietnam bitterness to its refusal to fully cut ties with the classic storytelling traditions of ‚ÄúThe Searchers‚Äù ‚Äî that blurbing Martin Scorsese‚Äôs most sordid masterpiece seems like a waste of bandwidth. But faced with the gravity of a true masterpiece, perhaps the most radical thing we can do is look at all the misinterpretations and cheap knock-offs it inspired and sincerely conclude that it was all still worth it to get the movie we did. It‚Äôs hard to think of a higher compliment to give a film than ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre the reason we got two ‚ÄòJoker‚Äô movies, and yet the world is still undeniably richer for your existence.‚Äù ‚ÄîCZ Paris in the daytime has never felt as desolate as it does in Jean Eustache‚Äôs 220-minute relationship drama. Presenting the collapse of May ‚Äò68 as the intellectual equivalent of Paris‚Äôs fall to the Nazis, the film depicts the city as an eerily barren metropolis populated only by small groups of emotionally atomized citizens each absorbed in their own diversions and work. No one embodies this retreat into solipsism better than Alexandre (Jean-Pierre L√©aud), a student leftist turned reactionary in the wake of the progressive movement‚Äôs collapse at the end of the ‚Äò60s. Ranting and raving about the failures of permissive society and the loss of traditional values, Alexandre nonetheless pursues two women he wants only for sex. Eustache‚Äôs film is an unsparing, eternally relevant overview of the manner in which jilted leftists can retreat into conservatism. The director even puts the ostensible progressivism of the French New Wave under a microscope, pointedly casting Nouvelle Vague poster child L√©aud and positioning his character‚Äôs unchecked cinephilia as just one form of his fetishization of the past. But the filmmaker also depicts ongoing resistance of a kind, as the gradually forming bond between Veronika and Marie offers a refusal to submit to Alexandre‚Äôs attempted reassertion of chauvinist power ‚Äî and a determination to retain the breakthroughs of the prior decade. ‚ÄîJC The most sinister and dreamlike of ‚Äô70s paranoid thrillers (its elusive sense of evil born from the unfinished state of David Giler and Lorenzo Semple Jr.‚Äôs script, the sociopathic disaffectedness of Gordon Willis‚Äô cinematography, and the two-note twinkle of Michael Small‚Äôs synth score), Alan J. Pakula‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Parallax View‚Äù is a film born from the creeping unease that settled into American life as the country‚Äôs post-war idealism began to seem like the ultimate cover-up. It‚Äôs a cover-up that Warren Beatty‚Äôs guilt-ridden journalist is determined to uncover, and ‚Äî in the wake of surviving a yacht explosion and foiling a bomb threat to a commercial airplane ‚Äî it almost seems as if he might be able to expose the plot to assassinate the most progressive senators who popped up after Kennedy was gunned down. If only a thick feather cut and a dream were enough to set the world to rights. No such luck for the fearless Joe Frady, who finds himself at the center of a plot in which heroes are little more than handsome patsies, and villains hardly seem to have faces at all. Staged with hypnotic impassivity from the moment it starts (the spectacular opening sequence atop the Seattle Space Needle all the more impactful for its casual disregard), ‚ÄúThe Parallax View‚Äù puts forward a much smarter and more calculated vision of a deep state conspiracy than the one we got. All the same, its closed-loop concept of American entropy ‚Äî and its unnerving insistence that the truth can kill you without fully revealing itself ‚Äî continues to resonate on a much darker wavelength than any of Pakula‚Äôs other ‚Äô70s classics. ‚ÄîDE First released 50 years ago, after Francoist censors convinced themselves that its anti-authoritarian messaging would have little social impact if buried under such a ‚Äúboring‚Äù art film, Victor Erice‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Spirit of the Beehive‚Äù follows a gullible six-year-old girl named Ana (Ana Torrent), who sees a screening of ‚ÄúFrankenstein‚Äù when a mobile cinema arrives in the small Castilian village where she lives with her family in the Spanish Civil War‚Äôs immediate aftermath. Confused and horrified by the sight of Frankenstein‚Äôs monster accidentally killing a child, and the townspeople then killing Frankenstein‚Äôs monster in return, Ana‚Äôs elder sister tells her that neither of those things actually happened ‚Äî that everything you see in films is fake. Later, with the memories of James Whale‚Äôs movie still fresh in her mind, Ana discovers a wounded republican soldier hiding in a sheepfold and decides to treat him with kindness instead of fear. It makes no difference to his ultimate fate. Ana‚Äôs sister was only half right in the end: ‚ÄúFrankenstein‚Äù may be a work of fiction, but fiction isn‚Äôt the same thing as ‚Äúfake.‚Äù Erice has only made three other features since his spellbinding debut, but all have been set in the same liminal space between film and reality that he explored in his first. As beguiling and hard to shake as any movie ever made (just ask Guillermo del Toro), ‚ÄúThe Spirit of the Beehive‚Äù sinks so deeply under the skin for its ability to fulfill cinema ‚Äî and ‚ÄúFrankenstein‚Äù‚Äôs ‚Äî promise of eternal return; its capacity as a magic trick capable of keeping the past alive long after it‚Äôs already died within us. The movies are real, Erice has always insisted. This one allows you to see that clearly. ‚ÄîDE As unforgivable as it is to reduce an Andrei Tarkovsky film to a 1:1 allegory for a specific current event, it‚Äôs hard to watch ‚ÄúSolaris‚Äù these days without feeling like it was made for 2025. It was probably made for quite a few other years too (many of which haven‚Äôt happened yet), but watching AI-generated recreations of deceased crime victims give interviews on talk shows and statements in courtrooms is a convenient reminder that Tarkovsky‚Äôs wisdom was ahead of its time.No other science-fiction film has ever been so bold in its assertion that science as a vocation isn‚Äôt all that great. ‚ÄúSolaris‚Äù begins with the scientific community doubting each other‚Äôs testimony to the point where they send a psychiatrist into space to audit ‚Äî and potentially shut down ‚Äî a research mission. When the cosmonaut makes it to the space station, he discovers that the crew‚Äôs unsupervised observation of the strange magnetic fields surrounding the ocean planet Solaris have driven one person to suicide and caused dangerous hallucinations among everyone else. And yet, despite being armed with all of the prior knowledge that nothing he sees on the ship will be real, our hero is powerless to resist a vision of his dead wife, which is is enough to make him abandon his scientific principles for a cheap facsimile of someone he once loved. It‚Äôs a moment of intellectual weakness and a major lapse in professional judgement, but anyone who says they‚Äôd act differently is lying to themselves. Tarkovsky mines the tension between the lofty ideas that guide science and the fallen nature of the humans who try to pursue them, and this sprawling, highly symbolic film is rife with many of the ideas that fascinated him throughout his entire career: that there are secrets in the world that humans aren‚Äôt meant to understand, that we‚Äôre fools to try and analyze things that should only be experienced spiritually, and that esoteric quests for metaphysical meaning are only undertaken by broken people with nothing better to do. Looking out the window towards a society that appears increasingly convinced to invent the technologies that will burn it to the ground simply because we have the technology to do so, we‚Äôd all be well-served to remember one of the film‚Äôs most profound quotes: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre in the foolish human predicament of striving for a goal he fears, that he has no need for.‚Äù ‚ÄîCZ ‚ÄúDays of Heaven‚Äù is a gem that has only grown more luminous with time. Filmmaker Terrence Malick was then still an emerging voice, now he‚Äôs viewed as one of American cinema‚Äôs most singular auteurs. After making his debut with 1973‚Äôs ‚ÄúBadlands,‚Äù Malick returned five years later with a film that‚Äôs as visually arresting as it is narratively elusive. Shot largely during the vaunted ‚Äúmagic hour‚Äù and steeped in natural light, ‚ÄúDays of Heaven‚Äù emerged from a notoriously difficult post-production process. The footage took two years to shape into a cohesive narrative, but the final product earned critical acclaim ‚Äî and four Oscar nominations, including a win for N√©stor Almendros‚Äô haunting cinematography. Nearly five decades on ‚Äî and with films like ‚ÄúThe Thin Red Line‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Tree of Life‚Äù only expanding his mythos ‚Äî Malick‚Äôs sophomore effort is seen not only as a foundational text in his body of work, but as one of the defining films of the ‚Äô70s. Its reputation rests not just on its painterly visuals, but on the dreamlike way it tells its deceptively simple tale. Richard Gere stars as Bill, a drifter who convinces his girlfriend Abby (Brooke Adams) to pose as his sister so she can marry a dying farmer (Sam Shepard) for his land. Linda Manz, who also provides the film‚Äôs ethereal voiceover, plays Bill‚Äôs actual sister, tagging along as the trio‚Äôs fragile arrangement begins to unravel. Like ‚ÄúBadlands,‚Äù ‚ÄúDays of Heaven‚Äù is remarkably lean. Despite the drawn-out editing process, the film clocks in at just 94 minutes ‚Äî a rarity in Malick‚Äôs later, more sprawling work. Within that brief running time, he crafts something hypnotic, lyrical, and emotionally resonant. The film‚Äôs centerpiece ‚Äî a literal blaze of glory on a wheat farm ‚Äî remains one of the most indelible images in American cinema. ‚ÄîRC An exploitation film released in 1974 with a title as shocking and to-the-point as ‚ÄúThe Texas Chainsaw Massacre‚Äù was never going to struggle to earn back its $140,000 budget, but that didn‚Äôt stop Tobe Hooper from reaching for the moon and tearing an irreparable cosmic rift in horror cinema. Stripped of the artificiality that tended to soften the genre, Hooper‚Äôs unvarnished masterpiece subjected moviegoers to some of the most nauseating imagery ever captured on film without so much as a moment to take a breath. The practical effects and the barbarity of the tool-powered killings hold up to this day, but it‚Äôs because of the film‚Äôs deceptively sophisticated pathos that it‚Äôs so entrenched itself in our collective psyche. Leatherface isn‚Äôt motivated by the kind of malice or revenge that drive so many other horror villains ‚Äî he‚Äôs a mentally disabled man raised by a perverse family with no means of supporting him after their jobs at the slaughterhouse disappeared. Forgotten by a society that was already beginning to rot, his family‚Äôs brutal actions were underscored by the notion that something similar could be lurking at the end of any innocuous-seeming country road.The scariest part of ‚ÄúThe Texas Chainsaw Massacre‚Äù is its utter nihilism. Hooper‚Äôs film remains so unsettling because of how blatantly it rejects the binary of good guys and bad, binary, offering us all a hideous reminder that we‚Äôre all just animals who are capable of inflicting unimaginable evils on each other once the paper-thin norms separating us from our instincts start to crumble. ‚ÄîCZ It‚Äôs all bad vibes and dark times in Nicolas Roeg‚Äôs hugely upsetting, weirdly tender, not quite sexy but surprisingly carnal study of mourning, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Look Now.‚Äù Julie Christie and Donald Sutherland bare it all and so much more as a WASP and a British Protestant who stare into the abyss of the absolute worst thing that could happen to any two parents ‚Äî their daughter drowning in the shallowest of ponds, right outside their own English countryside home. Where most contemporary horror movies that center on grieving couples (i.e. ‚ÄúAntichrist,‚Äù which blurs Roeg into Tarkovsky) tend to fling them to, say, a remote cabin in the woods as a backdrop for healing, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Look Now‚Äù instead sends its grief-dazed protagonists to the crowded canals of Venice, Italy. It‚Äôs there that Sutherland‚Äôs character, John Baxter, has agreed to restore an ancient church, hauling Laura ‚Äîwho seems almost suspiciously emotionally blinkered given recent events ‚Äî along with him. But the city‚Äôs rabbit-warren corridors, as established in Daphne du Maurier‚Äôs source novel, become M.C. Escher-esque grief portals as Laura becomes obsessed with a pair of supposedly psychic geriatric sisters. Meanwhile, there is a small person with a red hood ‚Äî the very one the Baxters‚Äô daughter wore the day she died ‚Äî running around the city. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Look Now‚Äù is most infamous for a sex scene nested within Roeg‚Äôs trademark style of cross-cutting, in which two events in parallel yet discrete timelines appear to be happening at once. John and Laura are both dressing and undressing, fucking and then not fucking, with armpit-licking and cunnilingus that shocked audiences and censorship boards and by present day standards certainly isn‚Äôt prude. But what it wasn‚Äôt, and isn‚Äôt, is gratuitous. On the contrary, it situates ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Look Now‚Äù as more emotionally raw-nerved romantic drama than true horror movie. Though you can‚Äôt forget the climax, which is one of the greatest of all cinematic rug-pulls, made all the more incredible by the fact that Roeg got away with it. This is the original ‚Äúelevated horror‚Äù: knockout performances, skillful craft, and a director who undersides the dual sides of manipulating and cajoling actors and who can elevate schlocky material. ‚ÄîRL According to Elia Kazan, Barbara Loden‚Äôs last words ‚Äî which she furiously spoke on her deathbed as her body gave out from breast cancer ‚Äî were, ‚ÄúShit, shit, shit.‚Äù Throughout their professional collaboration and marriage, the director ‚Äî who cast actress-turned-filmmaker Loden in ‚ÄúSplendor in the Grass‚Äù ‚Äî allegedly tried to undercut her autonomy and dismissed her creative ambitions. But the ambition of a woman operating below the studio system and out from her ex-husband‚Äôs eye paved the way for Loden‚Äôs ‚ÄúWanda,‚Äù a troubling, often grimly hilarious and Cassavetes-adjacent landmark in the history of independent film. Played by Loden herself, Wanda is as apathetic as any woman as we‚Äôve seen onscreen, languishing through life amid a pile-up of disappointments: She‚Äôs left her husband, granting him full custody of their children, and doesn‚Äôt protest when it‚Äôs time to sign the divorce papers. Loden, who had two children with Kazan, modeled the character after a version of herself: wandering, adrift, between jobs and between men, wedding her autobiography to a thinly sketched bank robbery plot that‚Äôs more background noise than the thrust of this existential tone poem of a 16mm-shot movie. One of the wisest, most piercingly drawn scenes in ‚ÄúWanda‚Äù finds the heroine idling through a shopping mall, matching eyes with mannequins that both reflect her own soul-drained blankness and the status divided between her dreams and achievements, these life-sized ‚Äúhuman‚Äù models adorned in clothes she could never afford. Here is one of the great portraits of a woman trying to find a place in the world, her world; she doesn‚Äôt find it by the end of the film, but the largesse of strangers (for food, for conversation, for cigarettes, for companionship) is enough carry her through another day. ‚ÄîRL In a pivotal decade of Hindi cinema, one film towers above the rest: ‚ÄúSholay.‚Äù Ramesh Sippy‚Äôs 1975 Western, penned by Salim-Javed, was initially panned and pegged as a flop, but a stark turn in fortune would soon put it on its path to legend. Amitabh Bachchan and Dharmendra star as Jai and Veeru, two petty criminals hired by former inspector Thakur (Sanjeev Kumar) to catch the deadly bandit Gabbar Singh (Amjad Khan) ‚Äî alive. The duo‚Äôs friendship is the emotional core of a film filled with love, loss, and vengeance, with supporting performances by Hema Malini, A.K. Hangal, Jaya Bachchan, and more. Indian films love to experiment with tone and genre, but the confidence of ‚ÄúSholay‚Äù set a golden standard. It starts as a buddy comedy filled with heists and hijinks, then slips into the sweet mundanity of village life with its rose-colored promises of the future. After Gabbar‚Äôs introduction, it goes full Western (but not without a ridiculous detour into Veeru‚Äôs love life). To watch ‚ÄúSholay‚Äù is to be sublimely entertained ‚Äî amused, shocked, charmed, moved, and everything in between ‚Äî and captivated by a voracious kind of filmmaking that grows rarer by the day. Bachchan and Dharmendra‚Äôs magnificent duo drives the film, and also parallels the pairing of Kumar‚Äôs dignified resolve and Khan‚Äôs anarchic villainy. R.D. Burman‚Äôs soundtrack delivered nostalgic hits like ‚ÄúYeh Dosti‚Äù and ‚ÄúJab Tak Hai Jaan,‚Äù which drive the story rather than interrupt it, and Salim-Javed‚Äôs dialogue is quoted across India to this day. It‚Äôs extraordinary that ‚ÄúSholay‚Äù became one of the most famous movies ever made, and all the more extraordinary that it earns every bit of its enduring popularity. ‚ÄîPK John Cassavetes, his wife Gena Rowlands, and his dear friend Peter Falk created a total explosion in 1974 with ‚ÄúA Woman Under the Influence,‚Äù which features some of the most searing and self-possessed screen acting of all time. Gena Rowlands‚Äô turn as mentally anguished housewife Mabel Longhetti remains a peerless master class ‚Äî an embodiment so soul-deep that it‚Äôs no exaggeration to suggest that it completely dissolves the barrier between performance and reality. But Falk holds his own as her husband Nick, who careens from serene ‚Äî and sensitive to his wife‚Äôs condition ‚Äî to throwdown impatience over her antics yet again, and again, and again. Originally, Rowlands and Cassavetes (who does not star in this film) envisioned ‚ÄúA Woman Under the Influence‚Äù as a stage play, but the intensity of Nick and Mabel‚Äôs emotional knockout fights ‚Äî leading up to Mabel eventually being all but 5150ed ‚Äî would surely have flattened Rowlands too greatly if she had to live it on stage multiple nights a week. Without studio backing, Cassavetes seemingly made the film with glue and paper clips, but you wouldn‚Äôt know that from the extraordinary control of craft on display, as much as ‚ÄúA Woman Under the Influence‚Äù doesn‚Äôt exactly present itself as a controlled film. It would be more accurate to describe it as a dizzyingly beautiful display of control being lost ‚Äî of a free fall in motion. Some 50 years later we‚Äôre still waiting to hit the ground. ‚ÄîRL ‚ÄúChinatown‚Äù is almost un-blurbable, and not only because it‚Äôs a film of such classical perfection in its Old Hollywood construction that its cavernous depths can only be fully appreciated with viewing after viewing after viewing. There‚Äôs the first viewing, where it‚Äôs easy to be taken in by its surface pleasures: John A. Alonzo‚Äôs nicotine-stain cinematography, Polanski‚Äôs apex-noir shot choices, Robert Towne‚Äôs seen-it-all dialogue, Jerry Goldsmith‚Äôs ominous lament for solo trumpet, little detective-movie touches like Gittes putting a pocket watch under a car tire to capture the time that someone‚Äôs peeled away, Faye Dunaway talking about the flaw in her iris. All of it is intoxicating. Then, maybe on the second viewing, you find yourself compelled to dig deeper into the real history of a city that literally stole its water from the poor farmers of Owens Valley in order to become ‚ÄúL.A.‚Äù ‚Äî a city of hunger built on thirst. Only in the viewings after that do the full crepuscular depths of this film‚Äôs black beating heart fully pump their way into your own bloodstream. John Huston‚Äôs Noah Cross is immediately shocking and repellant, but it‚Äôs only with prolonged exposure that one begins to recognize how deeply the personal, sexual, and political violence Cross represents is part of the historical fabric of this country. The ultimate act of a city and a nation holding a mirror up to itself (as is usually best achieved by an outsider to both, one indelibly marked by tragedy himself in his temporary adopted country), ‚ÄúChinatown‚Äù is really a mirror held up to a mirror, reflecting back a city and its dream reflections of itself over and over and over again. ‚ÄúChinatown‚Äù is the famous shot of a million Charles Foster Kanes repeated to infinity in Xanadu‚Äôs mirrors as an entire feature. It‚Äôs Jimmy Stewart looking into the abyss off the bell-tower roof in ‚ÄúVertigo.‚Äù It achieves that effect with a singularly devious subtlety. Chinatown‚Äù is an example of how true mastery always trumps virtuosity ‚Äî restraint over flash, craft over spectacle. It‚Äôs a cinema that‚Äôs grown up, that doesn‚Äôt believe in the lies of its dreamtown or of the medium best associated with it, but finds those lies ever-intoxicating and irresistible nonetheless. And it always comes back for more. ‚ÄîCB Rainer Werner Fassbinder effortlessly took to science fiction in ‚ÄúWorld on a Wire,‚Äù reorienting his recurring use of reflective surfaces as a means of illustrating both surveillance-state dystopia and identity confusion over the simulation program that presents its wired-in residents a false reality. That this simulation exists not merely to produce more docile citizens, but also to act as a kind of aggressive consumer testing for capitalist interests, only further stresses the dehumanization of the premise. For all of its heady concepts, however, the film finds the director frequently cutting loose with ideas, using the excuse of a constructed reality to freely blend imagery of 20th-century Germany and pop culture. A timely disco rave rubs up against a Weimar-esque cabaret, and the soundtrack runs the gamut from a performance of Marlene Dietrich classic ‚ÄúThe Boys in the Back Room‚Äù to Fleetwood Mac. This is one of Fassbinder‚Äôs most daring tribute/critiques of his nation‚Äôs addled and divided sense of self, at once at the cutting-edge of technology, economic growth, and culture but freighted by the immense burden of a history that lurks around every corner. ‚ÄîJC From the ashes of an aborted Napoleon film, Stanley Kubrick fashioned one of the most lushly beautiful movies ever made out of William Makepeace Thackeray‚Äôs picaresque novel about an Irish rogue who cons his way from lowly ruffian to nouveau riche nobility and back down again. Pioneering techniques for shooting in low-light and candlelit conditions, Kubrick and cinematographer John Alcott capture painterly landscapes worthy of Watteau and intensely detailed, densely populated interiors indebted to cheeky 18th century artist William Hogarth. Even the director‚Äôs usual icy mood and arch critical distance cannot preclude an immersive quality almost entirely unseen in period cinema to that point. Beneath the surface, though, ‚ÄúBarry Lyndon‚Äù is one of Kubrick‚Äôs funniest movies, wielding Ryan O‚ÄôNeal‚Äôs prickly personality to reflect the way that Barry‚Äôs social-climbing schemes usually succeed through bullheaded stubbornness rather than adroit manipulation. Ryan O‚ÄôNeal‚Äôs Barry is a loathsome boor who keeps failing upward, finding along the way that people at every rung of the hierarchy are equally petty and venal and differ only in their ability to dress up these flaws in politesse. ‚ÄîJC Djibril Diop Mamb√©ty‚Äôs ‚ÄúTouki Bouki‚Äù is one of the most stylistically inventive films of the 1970s. Made on a shoestring budget in post-independence Senegal, it follows two young lovers as they scheme to escape Dakar for Paris. The film‚Äôs fragmented editing, layered sound, and erratic structure reflect the characters‚Äô restless desire to leave ‚Äî as well as their confusion about what leaving really means. Both home and destination are shaped by the same colonial past. A landmark of African cinema, ‚ÄúTouki Bouki‚Äù remains a singular, disillusioned portrait of youth caught between dreams and dislocation. ‚ÄîTO A smirking meditation on authenticity that profiles art forger Elmy de Hory, hoax biographer Clifford Irving, and Orson Welles‚Äô Yugoslavian paramour Oja Kodar as part of an elaborate attempt to disguise its own trickery, ‚ÄúF for Fake‚Äù isn‚Äôt just cinema‚Äôs most playful self-portrait, it‚Äôs also its most dazzling statement of purpose. ‚ÄúArt is a lie that makes us see the truth,‚Äù Welles quotes Picasso as saying, and ‚ÄúF for Fake‚Äù offers an impossibly fitting gracenote to the career of an American titan whose work ‚Äî from ‚ÄúThe War of the Worlds‚Äù to ‚ÄúCitizen Kane‚Äù and beyond ‚Äî hinged on the power of showmanship in a world all too eager to believe its own eyes. And ears. ‚ÄúFor the next hour,‚Äù Welles proclaims in the first reel, ‚Äúeverything in this film will be based on solid fact.‚Äù But it‚Äôs the rest of time that ‚ÄúF for Fake‚Äù is most concerned with, and Welles‚Äô fascination with charlatans, forgeries, and doublespeak indeed cuts deeper than ever at a time when we‚Äôre all at the mercy of our worst hucksters. To revisit this endlessly knotted Magic Eye puzzle of an essay film today is to appreciate that nothing has changed beyond the sloppiness of the world‚Äôs sleight-of-hand. As Welles says of Irving‚Äôs fraud: ‚ÄúIt may well be the hoax of the century, but, really, this is not, you know, in any way the century of the hoax. We hanky-panky men have always been with you.‚Äù And they always will be. If only they took as much pleasure in it as Welles did. If only they gave so much of that pleasure back to us in return. ‚ÄîDE Released a year ahead of America‚Äôs bicentennial, Robert Altman‚Äôs panoramic view of celebrity and politics represents a high point of Altman‚Äôs experimental naturalism. Joan Tewkesbury‚Äôs script ‚Äî or blueprint, given Altman‚Äôs tendency to improvise ‚Äî splits the difference between New Journalism field reporting and biting social satire. The question of whether ‚ÄúNashville‚Äù celebrates or condescends to the music and people of the eponymous setting still incites debates. The film‚Äôs poignant, downbeat ending recalls the political assassinations that dominated the previous decade and presages the shocking celebrity-based violence that would come to define the remainder of the century. As Altman‚Äôs film strenuously argues, everyone wants to be famous, no matter what the cost. We‚Äôre way past the point where identifying that celebrity and politics are two sides of the same coin can be considered a novel observation, but Altman never lectures the audience about the idea anyway. He merely integrates it into the infrastructure. The gap between unseen populist presidential candidate Hal Phillip Walker, whose banal observations blare through the streets like hokey pabulum, and the aspiring singers that flit through the film‚Äôs margins is as thin as paper. Only Barbara Jean (Ronee Blakley), the fragile country singer constantly on the brink of a nervous breakdown, seems to recognize that fame is merely a gateway to being used by friends and strangers alike. Like all great works, ‚ÄúNashville‚Äù uses its narrow scope to probe at universal ideas‚Äîabout the ways social environments breed and warp personal aspirations and how the proliferation of images permanently distorted reality. In one sense, ‚ÄúNashville,‚Äù much like lothario singer Tom Frank, played by Keith Carradine, is easy, at least to describe in the abstract. But it‚Äôs much more difficult to explain the feeling of being immersed in its world. Altman and his players construct a lattice of pleasures and heartbreaks, vulnerable desires and duplicitous actions, local struggles and national wounds that rarely feel contrived or artificial. So much of the film feels like listening in on people‚Äôs lives, catching glimpses of their personalities as they move through the world, and projecting joy or sorrow onto their behavior. Altman allows his audience to get to know his characters, but he also keeps them at a crucial distance. It‚Äôs not unlike the experience of having a long chat with a stranger at a bar: you get to know them, but you will never perceive the full picture. This clash between familiar intimacy and fundamental unknowability at the heart of ‚ÄúNashville‚Äù lends it a uniquely peerless quality. Fifty years later, It‚Äôs still one of a kind. ‚ÄîVM The first time you watch Nagisa ≈åshima‚Äôs ‚ÄúIn the Realm of the Senses,‚Äù it might seem like more of a horror movie than a love story. This is, after all, a claustrophobic ‚Äî and broadly true ‚Äî saga of erotic obsession from the most hostile of Japanese auteurs; a mad and scandalous work of art that‚Äôs full of unsimulated sex, peppered with a massacre‚Äôs worth of little deaths, and topped off with a scene of genital amputation so unflinching that it feels like an answer to the eyeball cut in Bu√±uel‚Äôs ‚ÄúUn Chien Andalou.‚Äù Even if you‚Äôre willing to consider that Abe Sada chops off Ishida Kichiz≈ç‚Äôs penis as an act of love and mutual liberation, it still hurts to watch. The most notorious and universal of ≈åshima‚Äôs transgressions, ‚ÄúIn the Realm of the Senses‚Äù has never been at risk of aging, but its carnal revolt against the rising tide of militarism has only become more relevant over the course of recent years, as has its naked and pungent reaction to the dangers of living in a country that‚Äôs ashamed of all the wrong stuff. ‚ÄúLove of a country is a strange thing,‚Äù ≈åshima once said. ‚ÄúJust puffing out your chest with national pride and telling people how wonderful your country is does not constitute love of country as I see it. You have to tell the truth about your country, whatever it is.‚Äù ≈åshima saw ‚ÄúIn the Realm of the Senses‚Äù as a chance to seduce people into looking at themselves. It would be erotic but not titillating, arousing but not exploitative. It would offset the mucus, viscera, and verisimilitude of hardcore porn with the matter-of-factness of a nature documentary. In the end, it does all that and more. The film gradually becomes so cocooned inside its crust of dried sex that viewers start to get turned off just as they begin to realize there‚Äôs nowhere else for them to go. ‚ÄîDE A singularly crucial text in the myth of Werner Herzog, ‚ÄúAguirre, the Wrath of God‚Äù endures as cinema‚Äôs most lucid (self)portrait of the madness that some men develop in response to the sheer poverty of their own power ‚Äî in response to the hard fact that death is the only destiny that nature has put aside for them. It‚Äôs a film about how the hardness of that fact compels such men to invent a new destiny for themselves; how it gives them the will required to lead a suicide march in search of El Dorado, or in Herzog‚Äôs case the will to recreate one. The ecstatically true story of the 16th century conquistadors who splintered away from Gonzalo Pizarro‚Äôs expedition and disappeared into the Amazon rainforest, never to be seen again, ‚ÄúAguirre‚Äù is steeped in a fever from its opening shots, which find the Spaniards forcing their slaves down through the clouds of the Urubamba Valley as if descending into heaven. The biblical drama of the Peruvian landscape is further exaggerated by the clinical disinterest Herzog takes in the the human folly he stages against it (a reflection of the apathy the jungle shows to us all), which is set to the novocaine-like numbness of Popol Vuh‚Äôs airy score, and unravels with the natural calm of river water floating downstream. Klaus Kinski‚Äôs feral performance as the demented Aguirre is all the more affecting for how it preserves that sense of calm amid his character‚Äôs increasingly grandiose delirium. The actor‚Äôs jagged face had long struck Herzog as the only human landscape that could fully convey the destructive indifference of nature itself, and here in the first of their violent and spectacular collaborations Kinski is so possessed by mad pride that he seems to wield the wrath of god to the same degree he suffers from it. Movie characters have never been more primitive, but in a film so cut to the bone ‚Äî a film whose abject denial of poetry suffuses every scene with an inescapable unreality ‚Äî Aguirre‚Äôs wide-eyed sense of purpose is no less divine than Herzog‚Äôs determination to capture it on camera. ‚ÄîDE Ridley Scott‚Äôs ‚ÄúAlien‚Äù (1979) didn‚Äôt just explode the sci-fi genre ‚Äî it redefined what it meant to make a blockbuster with brains and blood. A haunting, slow-burn thriller with the visual sophistication of an art film and the unrelenting terror of a monster movie, ‚ÄúAlien‚Äù pushed the boundaries of genre cinema and delivered a protagonist who would go on to reshape the cinematic landscape: Ellen Ripley, played as only the brilliant Sigourney Weaver could. Weaver isn‚Äôt even the first name you see in the opening credits ‚Äî that honor goes to Tom Skerritt ‚Äî but by the time the credits roll, there‚Äôs no mistaking who this film belongs to. Ripley doesn‚Äôt start off as the obvious hero. She becomes one ‚Äî forged in trauma, quick-thinking, and sheer will. Her emergence 45 minutes in, amid a cascade of terror, feels revolutionary even now. Scott‚Äôs decision to re-gender the lead (originally written as a man by screenwriter Dan O‚ÄôBannon) was a seismic move. In an era dominated by masculine action heroes ‚Äî from ‚ÄúApocalypse Now‚Äù to ‚ÄúMoonraker‚Äù ‚Äî Ripley was a revelation: competent, logical, unshakably brave, but never stripped of her humanity. She doesn‚Äôt just survive the alien. She outwits it, outlasts it, and in doing so, becomes the rare kind of cinematic icon who actually earns her place in the pantheon. Weaver‚Äôs final showdown ‚Äî flamethrower in hand, fear in her eyes ‚Äî is the ultimate mic drop on a decade of genre excess. She saves the ship, the cat, herself, and maybe cinema itself. ‚ÄúAlien‚Äù isn‚Äôt just one of the best films of the ‚Äô70s. It‚Äôs a blueprint for how genre filmmaking can be smart, subversive, and unforgettable. Want the job done right? Send Ripley. Send ‚ÄúAlien.‚Äù ‚ÄîKE Francis Ford Coppola devotees ‚Äî and Coppola himself ‚Äî often like to describe ‚ÄúThe Godfather‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Godfather Part II‚Äù as one single, seamless film. But that well-intentioned praise falls short of capturing what Coppola actually accomplished with his sequel. After all, the only thing harder than making ‚ÄúThe Godfather‚Äù might be embarking on a follow-up to an era-defining film that is universally agreed to have a perfect ending. Coppola had more resources at his disposal the second time around, but the expectations were infinitely higher as well. Nevertheless, he still found a way to deliver a movie that deepens the ideas established in its predecessor without resting on its laurels or undoing any of the magic. Rather than give audiences more of the same, Coppola dove head first into a bifurcated narrative structure that illustrates the way the Corleone family‚Äôs future is inextricably linked to its past. As Al Pacino‚Äôs Michael Corleone sinks his claws deeper and deeper into a life that his father never wanted for him, relative newcomer Robert De Niro fills the massive shoes left behind by Marlon Brando in an origin story that washes away all of the lies these mafiosos tell themselves about their line of work: At the end of the day it isn‚Äôt about family or survival, but a simple raw lust for power and revenge that can never be satisfied. ‚ÄúPart II‚Äù will never be quoted or referenced as much as its predecessor, and it‚Äôs slightly easier to walk away from if you happen to stumble on a half-finished basic cable broadcast while flipping channels. But what it sacrifices in montage-able moments, it more than makes up for with its textual depth. The first film is a straightforward gangster movie executed at the highest possible level, but the follow-up is a morality play of cosmic proportions. Coppola never shies away from Michael‚Äôs original reluctance to seize the throne or the downsides of the job, but ‚ÄúPart II‚Äù rips away every semblance of glamour and shreds the family structures that made Michael‚Äôs success possible until we‚Äôre forced to discard every interpretation except the reality that none of this was worth it. If ‚ÄúThe Godfather‚Äù is the ultimate movie about a man who decides to sell his soul, ‚ÄúPart II‚Äù is just as definitive a portrait of what happens when the universe shows up to collect what it‚Äôs owed. ‚ÄîCZ It‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Godfather.‚Äù Francis Ford Coppola‚Äôs 1972 masterpiece remains one of the definitive films of the ‚Äò70s ‚Äî a decade that stands for cinematic reinvention and a Hollywood-backed turn to more nuanced storytelling. More than just a ‚Äúgangster movie,‚Äù it‚Äôs an operatic meditation on power, family, and corruption, wrapped in a mythic tale about the real price of the American Dream (read: pretty damn steep). And actors, boy, did we have actors back then. Marlon Brando‚Äôs unforgettable portrayal of Vito Corleone brought a weary, commanding presence to the screen, embodying the complex patriarch at the heart of this crime dynasty. Meanwhile, Al Pacino‚Äôs evolution from hesitant outsider to ruthless Mafia boss offers a masterclass in character transformation that fueled the film‚Äôs emotional core. Their performances, alongside one the best ensembles to ever be assembled on-screen, anchor a story that‚Äôs as intimate as it is epic. Coppola‚Äôs direction pairs perfectly with Gordon Willis‚Äô iconic ‚Äúshadow play‚Äù cinematography, creating a visual palette that feels both grand and suffocating ‚Äî a world drenched in darkness and moral ambiguity. Nino Rota‚Äôs haunting score adds a layer of melancholy that lingers beyond the screen, turning every scene into something timeless. Even all these years on, few films have been able to so ably interrogate what it truly costs to succeed in America, exposing the price of loyalty, power, and legacy with unflinching honesty. Decades later, ‚ÄúThe Godfather‚Äù remains a cultural touchstone, shaping not just the gangster genre but the very language of American cinema in the 1970s. It‚Äôs a film that captures the era‚Äôs restless spirit while standing as a timeless masterpiece. Not just one of the best films of the ‚Äò70s, one of the best films of all time. We don‚Äôt see that changing any time soon. ‚ÄîKE Chantal Akerman‚Äôs anti-epic is a film composed of all the quotidian bits of life that are usually elided through editing, its construction foregrounding how the daily tasks we consider too boring for the silver screen are more often than not also traditionally viewed as ‚Äúwoman‚Äôs work.‚Äù Akerman captures every chore of Delphine Seyrig‚Äôs housewife in such excruciating detail that even her moonlighting sex work becomes just another line on the to-do list alongside preparing meals and cleaning. And yet, in its deliberate lack of incident, ‚ÄúJeanne Dielman‚Äù slowly wrings tension out of the most banal variations on rigid schedules. A dropped utensil generates a jolt akin to Raymond Burr finally looking up into the camera in ‚ÄúRear Window,‚Äù and a break in Jeanne‚Äôs tic of turning off the light when she leaves a room hints at a blurring of her separate lives as a housekeeper and sex worker. These infinitesimal discrepancies accumulate like chaotic fractals that prefigure an explosive finale that would feel abrupt and nonsensical without them but becomes a logical catharsis thanks to the subtle breadcrumb trail Akerman scatters over three hours.
